review: Aug 21, 2021 i just rewatched this film for the first time in a few years and boy was it much better than i remembered. this film offers a new look at gotham compared to the dark, gritty criminal underworld present in the first two films. we can see a gotham that has prospered in the last few years, moving out of the darkness both figuratively and literally. most of the scenes in this movie are set in broad daylight, which is a refreshing change from the last two entries. tom hardy is excellent as Bane in this movie. he is the first villain in this series that truly feels like an unstoppable force. the moment where the whole plan comes together, the cops are trapped underground and bane declares anarchy on the football field was chilling and was the first time i felt as though there were real stakes from a villain. i do find miranda tate being the true villain an excellent twist. she is Bruce's reckoning, a cultivation of everything he has done and him quite literally facing his past dealings with the league of shadows and the consequences of his never ending work to protect gotham. i do wish they'd built up her relationship with bruce a bit more, though, as their romance did seem to come out of nowhere, but in the end it made the twist even more jaw dropping. this movie is long, and there is a LOT going on, but for the most part the pacing is pretty good. there were definitely parts that could've been cut out, this film suffers from agonisingly long and boring car chases like the dark knight does. other than that there isn't much i would change about this movie. anne hathaway is also spectacular in this movie and was very enjoyable to watch. i found myself enjoying every scene she was in and we get to see her grow from the selfish to the selfless across the movie. this movie also features great performances all round. out of the main ensemble i can't say there are any weak performances. my favourite scenes would have to be the ones of bruce in the pit. he is quite literally reborn there and the harrowing chants of the prisoners as someone attempts to climb is something that i always remembered from the first time i watched this movie. this movie excels at being the end of the trilogy - batman's final mission. with the highest stakes ever, and one of the most impressive villains i have ever seen in a superhero movie, it's an enjoyment to watch from start to finish. And in the final scene where we see the plane fly off with the bomb and batman inside it we are quite literally seeing the death of batman. bruce may still be alive but he has hung up the cape, and the batman died along with the bomb leaving a beautiful well-wrapped ending to one of the best trilogies of all time. i don't see much point making more batman movies after these ones, they are hard to flaw are greatly celebrated even today. afflecks batman wasnt great, but he still feels like he stands in the shadow of Bale, which i also worry will happen to Pattinson once "The Batman" releases. after rewatching the remarkable ending to a franchise it has got me thinking about how future movies can compete, and in my opinions batman should be left to rest for now. the dark knight rises is the perfect fulfilling ending to batman and his story
rt_name: The Dark Knight Rises - Movie Reviews

review: Aug 21, 2021 Not only is this the most intelligent Nolan film, really getting you to work as you watch the villain's plan unfold before you and the heroes, but it is also the most powerful in storytelling and moving the audience. Already you have the groundwork laid out from the previous film 'The Dark Knight' to follow up with Batman, running from the police who now has to tackle a new threat. It could not be done in a more mind-shattering and brilliant way. Bane's character, while seemingly a bit generic, quickly makes you realize how much you've taken him for granted when learning more about his backstory. Every time he walks on the screen he has a presence. I would say the same for the Joker, but he's been unfortunately memed too much for me to take him 'so serious' anymore. The way in which Bruce must rise again from the pit truly felt inspiring, and how he climbed out without the rope, the safety which he had always throughout the previous films. To me, that rope was symbolic of everyone he had with him throughout the films. Alfred, Rachel, and Dent as well. Now he had lost them all to the very same symbol which he crawls back to every night. He still finds the courage to put it on one last time. This time especially, I felt extremely interested in all other subplots in the movie. Gone was the fun but slightly stale 2000s grain and the lower mm cameras. This really plays up the aesthetic which Gotham is, and also allows for Gotham City to feel breathed in, as though people are really walking through it. This is something I never truly feel in any other Batman series or adaptation. To say this is the best Batman movie is an understatement. This really is the peak of Nolan's filmmaking for me. Everything from the acting, choreography, the score, and much more is such a step up from both predecessors. It never ceases to amaze me how much effort must have gone into this film. Ten out of **** ten

review: The Dark Knight Rises: 9.5/10 Goated, absolutely fucking goated. This is going to be like a combo of my review of the movie and just my general thoughts on the trilogy as a whole but in both regards it deserves nothing but the highest praise. Such a brilliant display of everything from audio-visual work to narrative structure and characterization this trilogy really does it all. The score was absolutely outstanding from beginning to end and in this movie I felt like the score did so much to amplify all of the scenes regardless of what was happening. The dialogue was amazing, iconic one liners and more subtle conversations that carry so much emotional weight it doesnt feel like a single line is wasted at any point which is extremely difficult to do. The cast is so well done, can we just talk about how this one trilogy has some of the best protagonists antagonists and side characters in all of fiction? Every character arc was explored and developed to its fullest from beginning to the end, characters that are introduced in one movie get the proper amount of development necessary to flesh out every aspect and ultimately creates some of the most iconic performances in all of media. This movie had that in spades, in particular it had a lot of really good development for Commissioner Gordon who was already one of my favorite characters in the trilogy but this cemented it for me. My favorite character in this movie in particular was Catwoman for sure, she served as a super interesting counterbalance for Batman acting as sort of a more self-serving out for herself version of him and god damn was it fun to watch. Amazing performance Anne Hathaway absolutely killed it, its honestly kinda nuts how well she fit the role imo. Bane was another really interesting character, had some great dialogue, and his characterization was really well done. I think one of the main themes of this trilogy is the idea of chaos and how it brings out the worst in people, and Bane is a fantastic device used to explore this idea. I think The Joker was the better device through which this was explored but like I think thats being a little bit unfair so its whatever, both are fantastic in their own rights. Also this ending might be one of the best most conclusive most satisfying endings to anything that I have ever watched or read, everything fit perfectly into place, I just wanted to see my boy Bruce happy and thats exactly what we got, the ending had me straight up crying it was so good. I came to become so invested in these characters over the course of these movies and it feels so good to see this trilogy end in such a beautiful way. This trilogy is absolutely goated in every way, shape and form, Christopher Nolan is a genius.,I'm not even mad that we didn't get any more it's absolutely perfect. Truly one of the best universes in all of media, I honestly don't even know what else to say other than the fact that its brilliant The Dark Knight Rises: 9.5/10 Goated, absolutely fucking goated. review: There's a lot of good in this film still. But it has neither as strong of a plot as Batman Begins or the stupendous fun of the Dark Knight. The climax is well done, but leaves unanswered still the question of whether Gotham can truly be saved, undermining the final product. Batman rides off into the sunset, but it is unclear that he has actually changed the city much for good - it still appears that it is only the same small group of individuals in the city who care for the city's character - not what Bruce Wayne took the mantle of Batman to do. Sure, he beats the bad guys in this battle, but he leaves the war while it's still being fought. That doesn't mean it isn't enjoyable, but it doesn't hold up to its predecessors.

review: Aug 9, 2021 Now this is how you close off an epic trilogy successfully! The Dark Knight Rises is the third and concluding chapter to Christopher Nolan's Dark Knight Trilogy, and is what I consider to be, a grand fitting end to the Christian Bale Batman/Bruce Wayne story arc. Released in 2012 to tremendous box office and critical reception, The Dark Knight Rises managed to become the highest grossing Batman film of all time, surpassing the hefty financial gain of The Dark Knight (2008), and still bares that title to this day. The Dark Knight Rises also has a few criticisms drawn from fans and critics alike, despite its mainly universal appraisal. Luckily for me, I'm not one of these hateful naysayers that hold any vice against this film. Drawing inspiration from various Batman comics storylines, such as "Knightfall," "No Man's Land," and "The Dark Knight Returns," The Dark Knight Rises manages to convey an engaging and effectively entertaining plot that's jampacked with numerous allusions, homages, colossal themes, and most importantly, a gratifying and emotionally powerful conclusion. Christopher Nolan really outdid himself with this production. Not only do we get a phenomenal plot, but we get phenomenal choreographed action sequences and intense visuals. The special effects alone are a treat to the eyes!! Christian Bale is remarkable in his final performance as Bruce Wayne, bringing us a battle-hardened, broken hero who must rise past his broken spirit (and broken physical limitations thanks to Bane and previous fights) in order to save Gotham City from total nuclear destruction. Familiar faces aiding him such as characters portrayed by Michael Caine, Morgan Freeman, and Gary Oldman bring their A-game in their final roles also. Newcomer Joseph Gordon Levitt does great as cop John Blake. And Marion Cotillard delivers an alluring, mystifying dual-identity role as Miranda Tate/Talia Al Ghul. But it's fellow newcomers Tom Hardy and Anne Hathaway that really stand out. The Bane we get in this movie is a lot different than the remedial one we get in Batman And Robin (1997); this new one portrayed greatly by Tom Hardy feels almost ripped straight from the comic books: an intelligent mountain of a man, who poses as both a physical and intellectual threat to Batman. Behind Heath Ledgers groundbreaking performance of The Joker, he's my favorite Batman villain in Nolan's trilogy. Anne Hathaway portrays Selina Kyle/Catwoman, a professional cat burglar, grifter, and femme fatale who develops a relationship with Bruce Wayne/Batman. She manages to evoke the sense of who Catwoman really is, and does such a great performance, she rivals Michelle Pfeifer's take on the character in Tim Burton's Batman Returns (1992). Lest we forget the intricate and meticulously well-shot 70mm IMAX cinematography? Or Han Zimmer's delightfully haunting musical score? Or every sliver of a detail perfectly synchronised to make connection and reference to the entire trilogy as a whole? No, lest us not forget. I still choose The Dark Knight as my favorite of Nolan's brilliant Dark Knight Trilogy, as well as my favorite comic book adapted film of all time; but The Dark Knight Rises will blow you away regardless
rt_name: The Dark Knight Rises - Movie Reviews

review: The Dark Knight Rises is DC's most successful movie: The Dark Knight trilogy is by far DC's most successful franchise with the combined gross total of the three movies being over 2.4 billion dollars with an additional billion in DVD Blue Ray and digital sales. The single most successful DC movie is the third movie in the trilogy, The Dark Knight Rises, which grossed 1.08 billion dollars worldwide. The second most successful DC movie is the second in a trilogy which grossed just over a billion dollars worldwide in 2008

rt_name: The Dark Knight Rises - Movie Reviews

review: The dark moral of a corrupt political climate that The Dark Knight Rises shows through Gotham's grief is really excellent when the perspective is put on the issue. With Bane's ever lasting commitment to pulling off pain in the city, and Miranda's morality with her revenge it sets off a never ending stream for the tone of the film to follow along. Then Bruce wanting to be his own nation "per say" and do it without the willingness of others around him. Focusing on the complexities of the film is what I loved during this rewatch. Half of the dark blend of Nolan's direction and the surrounding technicals are what send this film off another level. With each of his films he keeps that dark tone and hits a nerve on the edge of your seat with every picture he makes. With each shot he focuses his time on making it make sense and capturing the message and/or symbolism of the scene. I don't really talk about it that much because it never turned to conversation but honestly the greatest scene in this film is the Star Spangled Banner Scene. The symbolism of that is so impressive. Your honestly watching one of the most messed up scenes in the history of Cinema. By using that song in the angelic voice of that young child symboled the freedom Gotham felt, but we as an audience no good and well it's not. And the feel of the scene is so damn intense. I always notice that it's only the kid singing, noticing that nothing else is happening except the anthem of freedom being used as the last thing to be heard before that feeling of freedom is stripped away entirely. Bane then going on to say "that's a lovely, lovely voice" knowing good and well he's about to kill that symbol of freedom singing the anthem of freedom. After that scene the third act takes off and the film gets nothing but brilliant. The technical blend as well deals with the more explosive side of visual effects. They go so well with the film it's hard to take your eyes off. The character of Bane has to be the best part about this film. Not only is he so **** misused in other DC properties and gets his rightful spotlight, but Tom Hardy's ability to make such an evil character and use that flow of darkness that Bane is so viscously proves that Christopher Nolan can be a director to take risk, and that arc of doing all of this for Miranda was pretty much a great twist. And I'd just say I recognize the hate that Miranda gets for her twist of being the head mastermind and not Bane, but I honestly think that the writers so greatly used their minds to convincingly show why she was the one behind it. Overall, The Dark Knight Rises should go in the all time books, and be shown as a way to tell a unique perspective on political corruption.
rt_name: The Dark Knight Rises - Movie Reviews

review: The casting is still great. The gravitas of Oldman Caine and Freeman just add so much weight and levity to characters which could not have been anything special. Tom Hardy is excellent as Bane and I love the way they shoot scenes to make Hardy seem larger then he actually is. He is almost the representation of pure evil and is the definition of intimidating. His famous 'I will break you' line from Batman Knightfall in 1993 has lived on to one of my favourite comic series and I love the soft adaptation that it gets. Selina Kyle contributed to some of my development in this movie in the same way that Carrie Fisher as slave Leia contributed too many children's development. Marion Cotillard is good as Tate but probably the weakest actor as she gets really cheesy towards the end. It's ironic as she is one of the better actors as a whole but doesn't always bring it for this movie. The most underrated performance though comes at the hand of the main actor and Bale knocks it out of the park again. Probably his best performance in any of these movies. The action is easily the best in any of the Dark Knight trilogy. Its funny ironically however as it means that Catwoman has some of the best action. The jewel in the crown though is Batman vs Bane in the sewers which is so cool. Speaking of which this is one of those extremely quotable movies due to Bane. My favourite is easily 'oh you think darkness is your ally, but you merely adopted the dark. I was born in it Moulded by it, I didn't see the light until I was a man, by then it was nothing to me but blinding'. This all combines to make one of my favourite scenes when Batman escapes the pit and as a detail I love the bats coming out just before he jumps. Very rich plot. Its my favourite type of plot as if you are barely focusing on it you still get everything that happens but if you really focus you pick up every minute detail and I love those sorts of plots so much. The cameos also really surprise me as I didn't expect Scarecrow to rock up the first time I watched it. It's also miraculously well directed. Nolans over the city shots alongside his practical work, work wonders to create a realistic but also extravagant movie. His cinematography is also fantastic. It also continues the trend in his films to sometimes not have a concrete ending and in my opinion that works better. 10/10 I have no faults.
rt_name: The Dark Knight Rises - Movie Reviews

review: The film, the Joker, is about Arthur Fleck. For a living, Arthur works as a clown who deals with mental illness. He lives in Gotham City with his elderly mother and must take care of her. Arthur is constantly mistreated by society which is present throughout the film. When his social worker tells him he won't be able to get his medication anymore because the government is shutting them down to save money, this creates a major impact on Author and other citizens in Gotham who deal with mental health problems. This film has caused controversy because some believe it could give people ideas of mass shootings. The movie did not motivate mass shootings. It also did very well in theaters and many people, even if they don't know anything about DC Comics, really enjoyed the film. The Joker also had a very successful box-office run and won awards. The twists and surprises in this movie make it worthwhile and will have the audience on the edge of their seats. The opening scene of the Joker sets a dark tone for the rest of the movie. It shows how society treats people like Arthur and makes the viewer feel bad for him. Joaquin Phoenix who plays Arthur, was an incredible choice for this role. Joaquin's movements, emotions, and laugh really made the viewers sympathize with him as well as really helped the Joker come to life. The card Arthur must give to those who are confused why he is laughing is significant. This was a great way to introduce Joker's iconic laugh to the audience and to the citizens of Gotham city. A significant action Arthur does in the beginning of the movie is using his fingers to make himself smile while in clown make up. The reason this is important is because he is putting on a mask to make it seem like he is happy but, on the inside, he is struggling. Later it shows Arthur in his apartment with all his medication he has to take which makes him feel like he is just going through the emotions. The first subway scene shows how Arthur is being picked on because of his mental illness by laughing in a serious situation. This causes Arthur to make a rash decision and causes an uprising. The director Todd Philips did an amazing job picking the cast members. Each scene was important to this story as it went on. The close ups and zoom-ins, like Arthur sitting on the train after getting told he will be on the Bill Murray show, show how important and make you focus on that detail. After, Arthur goes to the Arkham Asylum, one of the many important parts in the movie. In this scene Arthur realizes about his past and what his mother, Peggy, went through. This scene is also huge because mental illness is a big issue in society today and makes people realize how big of an impact it can have on people. When Arthur leaves the Arkham Asylum you begin to piece together the hallucination he had with his neighbor. This begins to make viewers question what parts were hallucinations and what parts were really happening? The music in that scene is a great choice. The soundtrack to the film all fits together and was picked very well. This film is also interesting because unlike most movies about the Joker he is always battling Batman. But in this it takes place before Batman is Batman. It gives an insight into why the Joker became a villain and shows at one point he was a member of society, following the rules of Gotham. Another scene that was created well was when Arthur starts to transform into the Joker, by dying his hair and putting on clown makeup. Another scene is when he is dancing down the staircase. This scene is powerful because he is in his suit, clown makeup, and green hair. The music for this scene pulls it all together, it was a great choice and his dancing to the music is perfect. This is also showing his transformation from Arthur into the Joker. The scene on the subway when everyone is wearing a joker mask is powerful. This helps Arthur escape from the police, and it shows people turning on the police as well. The riot in the subway helps the cause of Arthur. The slow motion of him walking away from the subway while police run into the subway shows how confident Arthur has become and how much more confident, he is becoming. When Arthur is being pulled out of the cop car by fellow rioters and is placed on the hood of the car is symbolic. This is symbolic because there are citizens of Gotham who believe Arthur is right about the way Gotham is being run, which ties into his later encounters with Bruce Wayne. When Arthur uses his own blood to put a smile on his face and the crowd cheers, is the point when Arthur is no longer in control and the Joker has now taken over. The song ‚ÄòThat's Life' is a great fit for this movie, which is played a few times throughout. It represents how even though society has not been kind to Arthur or others like Author, he still persevered through it and is taking actions into his own hands. On a scale from 1 to 10, 10 being the highest score, I would rate this movie a 10. This movie can relate to issues in society today and is a realistic portrayal, unlike a lot of villain movies. It was directed incredibly well, and each scene is important to understanding the character arc the main character goes through. It also brings up mental illness which is an incredibly big issue today. Although Arthur's mental illness is very extreme, it still sheds light on how impactful it is on people. The background music in all the scenes match perfectly with the characters' attitude and show the seriousness of each situation. This really helps show how Arthur transformed into Joker and even when he wasn't telling you still understood the emotions he was feeling. It also shows how little Gotham did for the poor and mentally ill citizens. Todd Philips did a great job with bringing his idea to life and making people empathize with Arthur Fleck.
rt_name: Joker - Movie Reviews

review: When I went to see this movie in theaters I was 15, I walked into that theater expecting another lazy, box office flop of a DC film. but Mr. Phillips proved me wrong, very wrong in fact. this film took my breath away, I walked out of the theater lost for words, stunned, on the verge of tears from true joy. This is the film I never knew I needed in my life. This is the film that defines the word "perfection", with it's heart wrenching score, the amazing cinematography of a disconsolate Gotham City, and we can never forget the OUTSTANDING performance by Mr. Phoenix, getting him a very well deserved Academy Award. there will never be another film like Joker, ever. this is the best film of all time.

review: From the outset, the Joker feels like a mirror world, wherein violence is rampant in the streets, and the share of voice lies between the burners and the other, more educated, and more justified, burners. Until you realise there is no mirror, and this is a perfectly silent megaphone into our current state. The question you are left answering is this - who is the Joker?

Lastly, the production design is fantastic, the 1980s aesthetic is incredible.

review_date: I wish we could have seen the middle entry of the trilogy Abrams opened with Episode VII. As it stands, while this movie does what it can to return to form, its nostalgic trip down memory lane rings hollow without context. Unearned heroism meets unearned villainy meets unearned redemption in this slapdash first, second, and third installment in a hasty fourth Star Wars trilogy, after The Last Jedi decided to deny any intriguing answers to the questions posed by its predecessor. Little can be said about this film except that it just isn‚Äôt very good, to no fault of its own. Had The Last Jedi honored any of what came before, this finale could have been so much more than the hasty, inarticulate mess it turned out to be.

review: Rating: 8/10. 88/100. | I don't care what people or critics say, this is the best Star Wars film, to me. And it should be looked upon as the 3rd or 4th best by overall consensus. There's some problems but eh. This film is what solidified this saga for me. At first the highest i rated one of the films was a 7.6 for "Empire Strikes Back". Granted, I was torn about my ratings from the get go, but this film is what really awakened my true feelings. Empire went from a 7.6, to a 7.9, and then after this film, an 8.7. This film barely beating it, at an 8.8/10. I mean, I know it might change later, just like it has been, but for now I feel confident enough about my ratings and reviews; which is a first, ever since I started this saga. The Star Wars Saga went from a good franchise, to being one of my fav universes/franchises in film history. It gripped the Force around me, and now I love it and the Force is with me. This is the way.

review: It's hard to even encapsulate my thoughts in words, because I'm not even sure what I witnessed. Like watching a person in a wheelchair topple down a flight of stairs, I want to do anything to help, and yet I can only sit back and watch aghast knowing that there's only suffering left. This is immensely sad it becomes comedic, in a deeply mournful way. It feels impossible to make a mockery of something with such a powerful legacy such as Star Wars. But Rise of Skywalker somehow exceeded all hopelessly low expectations to be an absolute travesty of filmmaking. I've heard that this was an attempt to reset from the mistakes made in The Last Jedi. And yet the entire runtime of the film is filled with MORE mistakes, nothing of which resolves or absolves the previous poor filmmaking, and all which only makes the situation worse than it already was. It's as if Abrams gave up before he began, attempting to juggle far more than he knew he could, dumping his entire juggling act on the floor, shrugging, and walking away even though he was paid to entertain. The first part of this film is exhausting. The nonsense jump-cutting from scene to scene at (quite literally) lightspeed is so disorienting. It was so hard to wrap my mind about even what the general plot or objectives were as it bounced between conversation and action spectacle. Only when Lando Calrissian makes an obligatory cameo that I was somehow drawn out of my drunken stupor, and realized that I was actually watching a beloved series near and dear to my heart. And then I saw that series so bastardized that it was hard not to sit back and mock the entire thing. Jedi ghosts have super powers! Rey also has healing superpowers, wowee! Is that Palpatine? What's he doing there? Look at all those sith in coliseums. Why are they there? Who knows! It's just nonsense. To think of all the controversy there was when the new trilogy was originally debuting, and the entire Star Wars canon had to be reset just to make it make sense; knowing this is where it all ended up, it's almost a joke that the lore needed to be reconstituted at all. This series stomps on everything you love and acts happy about it. And you're meant to feel joyful that everything you love has been destroyed, truly and completely. You're meant to like this. This is most certainly one of the worst films I have seen in a very long time. My disappointment is immense.

review: Just as we thought it couldn't get any worse... After a great deal of suffering from watching The Last Jedi... JJ has to come back and try to fix this trilogy, an impossible task I'd say, and I'd be correct. This movie is a mess with MAJOR plotholes, and it seems like it satisfied the fans? I don't get that, maybe the positive reaction stems from the after-shock of having to watch Rian Johnson's attempt at butchering the whole franchise, but this movie seriously lacks the Star Wars charm, which George Lucas gave us with his film. The reason why The Force Awakens is held higher than the two later instalments into this sequel trilogy is because that movie has the Star Wars charm, and the nostalgic feeling and hype around watching Star Wars again got to us all. There is serious potential wasted in this sequel trilogy, JJ played it safe, Rian ruined everything, and this is the attempted clean-up... This is a sad attempt, Disney, maybe you should try to bring in a George Lucas or a Dave Filoni in a supervising role or something. Both of them know how to handle this franchise. George seems to be more than happy to help, and Dave Filoni is already your employee. Disney, you failed yet again, and yet again you held all the right cards, but chose to play the wrong ones instead.

review: This is a movie, that even now I still can't really make my mind up about. Like, I enjoyed it, I'm giving it a positive review, but it's easily the weakest of the entire franchise, and I actually don't think it's that close. The biggest problem is that this isn't a "Toy Story" movie; it's a movie completely about Woody. Everything is around him, not the rest of the toys. Because it's the fourth film I guess they can do that, but imagine if like a seven year old went with his or her family to watch this movie. They'll like it, but are they going to remember characters like Jessie, Bullseye, and the rest of the gang like the other three films? No, they're just not. In the other three films it felt like the screen time for all the characters were perfectly balanced. In this movie, however, again, it's all about Woody. Another big thing is that the new characters are really either a hit or a miss for me. Like I love Duke Caboom, but not really that tiny officer toy thing. It's like the same thing that Toy Story 3 has, just more of a distraction, at least for me. Now, with all of that said, this is a really enjoyable movie to watch. Animation is great, I like the story enough, but what's not talked about is the setting. Putting this story in a carnival was such a smart idea, and it can lead to a lot of good "action" shots. So yeah, I'm recommending it, just don't expect the same impact the other films had. There was really only one scene that left a huge impact for me, and without going into spoilers, it involved Gabby Gabby, the villain. I would put on a lot more Pixar movies before this one, but I wouldn't mind taking this one out of the toy box every now and a then. Go to Disney+ and make you're own opinion on this probably ending of arguably the best animated franchise ever!

review: Toy Story 4 was pretty good. The animation was top notch and the best out of all of them. The story on the other hand needed some work. I honestly think that this movie should've had a subtitle under it because this feels more like a Woody movie than a a stand alone Toy Story film. I have no problem with it being a Woody movie but the movie is called Toy Story. With this I did expect the story to be about Woody and the toys not just mostly Woody himself. Sure the new characters like Forky, Gabby Gabby, Ducky and Bunny, and Duke Kaboom were memorable and fun to watch it just would've been more entertaining with the other toys that are there. However despite the movie's flaws there's a lot that I enjoy in this one. I enjoy Woody and Bo Peep's relationship. I actually enjoyed the father figure between Woody and Forky and I also enjoyed Bonnie experiencing school for the first time. However my favorite thing about this movie is the ending. I just loved how this movie ended. I really like the idea of Woody doing what he wants for wants he really wants to be with Bo Peep and he finally gets to do that is just so satisfying. This brings so much character development from Woody and opens the door to so many possibilities to tell knew and interesting stories for the toys. So overall was Toy Story 4 perfect? No, but it does do a lot of interesting things to not only keep you engaged but to also make you feel satisfied. 9/10

review: As Andy is preparing for college, his favorite toys accidentally get donated to a daycare instead of being stored in the attic. It is truly amazing that the story tellers at Pixar can continually add a fresh take on these characters with every sequel. All the voice actors do a great job continuing or introducing their characters. Lotso is a well written villain with a sympathetic backstory. The animation is terrific and it is amazing how the look of these characters have changed since the first Pixar movie. The ending will bring tears or warm-fuzzies depending on your mood. Highly recommended movie and a great ending to one of the best trilogies in cinematic history.

The reason it's my least favorite, however, is because the dark tone really scared me as kid, Lotso terrified me, and the movie itself, in my opinion, is kind of dated because all the scenes in Sunnyside were so disturbingly unwatchable to me. Overall, this movie was a great conclusion, and superbly should've that way.

review: Man‚Ä¶.did Pixar kick off this decade with a bang with another 5 out of 5 movie! The last couple of Pixar movies have been some of my personal favorites, with Cars more suiting as a guilty pleasure than anything else. However, I think Toy Story 3 is better than all of those films by a good bit. First, the story and plot. It's a prison break movie, which I'm already a sucker for. Combine that with the Already great storytelling of Pixar, and you have a chefs kiss for it! Next, the villain. Lotso is probably the best Pixar baddie since Syndrome. He has a great backstory, and for the majority of the film, he wins, which is kind of insane. Now, let's talk about the animation: it's perfect, not too much to talk about there. And the ending, OMG the ending! It's such a great way to end the movie. If I had to nic pic one thing, it's probably the plot line of making Buzz a space ranger again, that seemed a little lazy. But that means we got Spanish Buzz, the funniest part of the film, so it doesn't affect the quality of the movie at all. The question really is is this the best Toy Story film? To me at least, I like the second more, the sole reason being that I like the characters introduced in that one better than this one. Not to say the new characters are bad in anyway, but are they going to leave as big an impact as Jessie or Bullseye? Yeah, me neither. This is a great film, and a perfect way to end this franchise‚Ä¶.too bad they made another one, but that's for another review. Go to Disney+ and watch the next perfect Pixar flick!
rt_name: Toy Story 3 - Movie Reviews

review: Toy Story 3 was pretty good l. Not as good as the first two but it was still a pretty solid feature. I really enjoyed the characters in this movie. They continue to be so fun and entertaining to watch. I really love the villain Lasso and just love how he went from kind hearted to ruthless in the end. I also like the idea of a prison break out of a summer camp. And I also really like how they keep on bringing memorable new characters. And the ending of the film does put you on the edge of your seat. However even though I like the ending of this movie I think it would've been better if it had a tighter good bye to Andy. I think it should've had a little bit more time to feel the emotion through Andy, Woody, and Buzz. But other than that I really enjoyed this movie. The animation is the best out of the other two and I really enjoyed spending more time with these characters. All in all good movie. 9.9/10

review: The sequel to Curse of the Black Pearl features the return of Captain Jack Sparrow as he and several other interested parties seek out Davy Jones and his chest. Johnny Depp returns as Sparrow and continues his brilliant performance as the character. Bill Nighy's performance as Davy Jones is also really well done. There are some memorable action sequences, though a few of them linger on too long. Hans Zimmer does an excellent job taking the music from the original movie and creating new material and themes that become a staple of the franchise. The plot to this film is more complicated than the first and may lose a few audience members along the way, with the run time not helping. I think this is an excellent sequel and I highly recommend that you check it out.

review: A rather unpopular opinion, but "Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest" is actually my favorite of the original trilogy. Once again the performances are great, and the characters are as great as they were in the first. However this time around, we get introduced to an even more compelling villain than Barbossa from the first film: Davy Jones. Davy Jones is the best villain the "Pirates" franchise has to offer. Besides Jones, another aspect of this film that I think puts it above the first is the plot. It's more complex than the first film, yet oddly enough just as easy to follow, making for a very satisfying viewing experience.

review: I really don't care what anyone says, this was a good movie. Yes not quite as good as the first, and definitely not 5 stars worth (just trying to get that average up lol). On the complete off chance, someone stumbles upon this review who has yet to watch the movie (that's got to be one niche market haha), it's fun, action-packed, has literally the best CG villain of all time, and actually an ok plot. Honestly don't get the hate for number two, it's still got a lot of the good qualities of POTC and hasn't yet gone threes route of being a bit ott and down right messy righting wise. Zimmer's new additions to the score are also very welcome, Klaus did a fantastic job with the first movie, but honestly I think he'd gone as far as he could with creating an incredibly iconic theme. Needed Zimmers expert touch to do the more subtle love themes and breath more life than solely reusing the same old main theme again and again. So yeah, great movie over all

review: Nowhere near as good as the phenomenal first movie but it's still a good movie. Like the first movie, the visuals, music, costume, makeup and set designs are incredibly impressive, the acting is just as good, the film is honestly funnier than the first, it's a much darker movie, the characters are just as great and have clear motivations and once again, we get amazing pirate action scenes especially with the Kraken, the Will vs Norrington vs Jack fight and I love the ending where Sparrow comes back to ‚Äòdefeat' the Kraken. Seeing Will's father was also heartwarming and Davy Jones is a great villain and is built to be an intimidating threat but it's flawed. The tribe scene (whilst hillarious) adds nothing to the plot, Beckett does nothing throughout the movie but sit in an office and I just don't find the plot as intriguing as the first movie. It's basically a treasure hunt story without the obstacles. It seems more focused on characters than telling a fun story and because the story isn't over yet, it's also not entirely satisfying but it's still a good movie but the first movie was way better.

review: Honestly, the second Pirates movie outshines the first in many ways. The first is a classic but this one continues to expand the world that Pirates is set in as well as has a bigger budget, which results in more flesh out and better-produced scenes. This movie has the best fight scene out of all the pirates' movies. It is well choreographed and worth its 2 hour run time. The actors are more comfortable in their characters and the writers know exactly where they want to take the plot. A fantastic movie that is full of surprises even to those who love the franchise. The movies keep getting better!

review: What this movie lacks in originality it more than makes up for with its out of this world visuals the detailing on the animal's fur is some of the best CGI I've ever seen in any movie (its especially amazing on the big screen) it almost feels like a national geographic documentary and shows how far computer rendering technology has come unfortunatley Disney has turned one of their best movies ever into a lazy cash grab by doing a shot for shot remake despite that they still put alot of effort into researching African wildlife and making it as realistic as possible I love what they did with the hyena queen character she is much more viscous and scary than the original her fight with Nala was better than simba vs scar. scars death is even darker and more graphic than the original they actually show him being eaten alive by hyenas if only they brought back Jeremy irons to voice him despite the fact that Disney copied and pasted the story of the original its still visually stunning and definitely worth the watch

review: The word "soulless" covers most of my issue. The voice acting was entirely lacking heart, and in some cases was simply given poor direction. (Mufasa roars, and asks "Is that a challenge?" As if he's inviting Scar to tea.) John Oliver was entirely out of his depth, Ejiofor gives zero malice to the role, Beyonce over-sings every line, and Seth Rogen's perfectly played irreverence stands as the one bright spot. Disney took a swing and a miss with this one.
rt_name: The Lion King - Movie Reviews

review: I have NOT been a fan of the rehashed remakes that Disney have put out as of late (Beauty & The Beast, Aladdin, Mulan...UGH...,Lady & The Tramp...not bad but mediocre) though I have 2 exceptions, The Jungle Book and this latest rendition of The Lion King. To be real, there's never gonna be a Lion King rendition that's gonna come anywhere close to the 1994 classic, let's be honest with ourselves. However for it's credit, this remake did not want to make me leave the theater in disgust. If anything it's a good movie that it's worth a watch, you just gotta dial down your expectations of the movie because some parts of it are kinda watered down and a bit of filler moments are put in there too which would explain this movie being 25 minutes longer than the original. Other than that, it does follow the script to the letter and makes for a good nostalgia high with modernized graphics. Props to the CGI team, this movie does look beautiful, probably the highest mark of the movie. It's not a bad Disney movie at all, the unfortunate part is that it does not surpass what the animated classic has already brought out to us and those are shoes that are almost impossible to fill so I can understand this movie falling short in some parts. It does make for a good comparison of what is being brought to this generation versus what my generation got as a kid growing up in the 90's.
rt_name: The Lion King - Movie Reviews

I found myself constantly comparing it to the original, which was distracting, but unavoidable since it is essentially the same script with many of the same visual cues, while also being confused by the "realistic" animation. When Mufasa dies, Simba's reaction is pretty much impossible to read. The characters were less sympathetic as the animation wasn't as expressive as the original, which made this one a bore.

review: 6.75/10. This adaptation of the cartoon classic is a nearly beat-for-beat, shot-for-shot retread of it's forbearer. It feels less like a remake or re-imagining than a remaster - viewers who want a new spin on a classic will be disappointed to find they are paying to see a movie they've already seen (albeit with a new coat of paint). While it's a shame that director/producer Jon Favreau added nothing new to this tale (despite proving his capabilities with 2016's vivid and fresh 'The Jungle Book') it manages to retain the soul of the original and is sufficiently entertaining. Excellent voice and vocal performances couple with stunningly life-like depictions of wild Africa and it's animal inhabitants to satisfy fans hoping to relive an old favorite, while offering new viewers an experience approximate to what the rest of us experienced in 1994, albeit with less facially emotive animals.

review: An absolutely great film that captures the charm and originality that "Star Wars" is known to have. "Rogue One" beautifully ties the prequels to the original trilogy, providing loads of new and memorable characters while also giving us some rather forgettable ones. The CGI is the best in any "Star Wars" films, and the entire story feels darker though still very welcome. The action is also done very well in this, and the worldbuilding is still very spectacular. About the only bad thing I can really think about this film is that there is quite a number of instances of fan service, though I think that this film handles it better than most other films do. Jones, Luna, Mendelsohn, Yen, and Tudyk are some of the better actors that really give it their all in this film. The humor is also very well and lands a majority of the time. Overall, a very rewatchable film that stands as one of the better "Star Wars" films made to date.

review: One of the best Star Wars films ever made, and certainly the best one made during Disney's ownership of Lucasfilm. This movie took a risk by dispensing with the orthodox Star Wars formula by not being focused on the Skywalkers, and instead introducing a new set of main characters who all died at the end. The risk paid off. A change in pace from the normal style of Star Wars films worked well. It was nice to watch a Star Wars film without countless scenes about the force and pompous Jedi preaching. Instead we had an intertaining action film which expanded the lore of the Star Wars universe in an interesting and exciting way. The final Battle of Scarif was very well executed, with an epic space battle and a satisfying and unorthodox ending. My only issue with this film is the character of Cassian who was supposed to evoke some sort of false-equivalency between the empire and the rebellion with his stories of committing unforgivable war crimes for the rebellion. This might be a good point regarding conflicts in the real world, and it might have worked in Star Wars but it was awkwardly executed and unbelievable considering the very black and white perspective we get on good and evil in other Star Wars films.
mojo_name: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story

review: I watched for the second time a few days and this time I enjoyed more than the first time. The plot is intricate and the first time I was trying to work out what was going on and so not appreciating the other aspects of the film. I thought all the lead actors played their parts well especially Felicity Jones as Jyn Erso. I think the visuals of this form are more artistically beautiful than the Lucas films - maybe that's the strength of Disney. I also found the plot more convincing. With the original trilogy the main stars always manage to miraculously survive but in such a conflict that wouldn't generally happen. Also the discussion of the morality of war and conflict in the rebel alliance added to the more realistic feel of this film. The good guys are not all good, This seems to be a Star Wars film that has grown up and lost some of the juvenilia of earlier films.

review: Gorgeous sets and animation along with a great cast (with the exception of Jafar, although I do love Marwan Kenzari in "The Angel"). I really do believe, especially in the case of Aladdin, that if Disney diverted more from the animated originals and drew more from the original source material to create darker, more mature, and more nuanced takes on their classic films, it would make for much more compelling stories and a much more compelling reason to justify these remakes' existence.

review: 85/100. This live action adaptation of the classic cartoon is one of the best live action Disney movies to date. Will Smith not only did the Genie role justice but he knocked the performance out of the park. Naomi Scott and Mena Messoud played both of their characters very well. All of the musical numbers were done to perfection, as well as the new songs included in the film. The animation looked great, even making a big blue Genie look like he belongs in our world. The only major gripe I have with this movie is the actor who played Jafar was nowhere near as harsh and menacing as the character was in the original. All in all, even if you do not like live action remakes and are worried they will ruin your favorite film, you do not need to worry with this version of the film. In fact, I may even like this live action adaptation better than the original.

review_date: The live-action remake of Disney's hit film 'Aladdin' is a fresh and fun return to the wondrous world we experienced in the animated version. The remake does a wonderful job of staying loyal to the source material while also taking great steps to represent its female characters much better by giving Jasmine a better storyline and her own musical numbers. The visuals are stunning and the musical numbers are insanely well realized in live-action. Will Smith does great as his version of the Genie, which he ensures doesn't undercut the amazing performance from the late Robin Williams' version of the character.

review: Aladdin (1992)  1 year ago  Meh... Genie; ironically based on previous consensus saved this movie. The opening feels rushed and they changed a lot about the movie to be P/C (the opening song being just 1 example). They also tried WAY too hard to be empowering to women... to the extent they got rid of anything that seemed over-objectifying and gave Jasmine a new song and other quirks that come off as offensive to people in the middle east who have gender roles as a cultural norm. It was a bit tragic given my wife lost interest in the first 25-35 minutes and things finally picked up a bit only to flop around a bit. However she did think the genie freedom scene was pretty nice.

review: Pirates 4 is an interesting movie because it followed up such a successful trilogy and I know some see this movie and think that it is awful. Some parts were not enjoyable to watch. The pacing seemed off and the script a bit wonky. A noticed a few plotholes where they could've added something different or replaced that whole segment. All in all, I did like the fourth installment of the Pirates franchise. The characters were perfect for the world and I did enjoy how it focused on Captain Jack Sparrow. We all have a sense of nostalgia for the first ones that this movie sadly doesn't have on its side. The end made me hopeful for the next movie with all the pieces in place for another movie. I do recommend it.

review: This is definitely the film that I have the most mixed feelings about. But I finally came to a consensus after re-watching it again. The issue isn't with Captain Jack like Pirates 5 were they completely threw away who he is as a character. No, in this one he is great and exactly the character he's suppose to be in fact I would say this is Depp's best Captain Jack performance since the first one which definitely adds to the film. The big problem with this movie is it banks on the audience connecting and caring about what happens to all of these new characters which just isn't the case. In fact the only familiar faces&people the audience cares about were Barbossa and Jack which are still great characters and all but there was none of the buildup like in Pirates 2&3. Because by the end of the movie nothing has happen except that a few new characters that we barely got an introduction to died which has no relevance to the series. That aside however there were some great scenes with Capt. Jack and Barbossa the palace scene for example and in all is certainly not as bad of a film as Pirates 5. So in all I would say a solid 7/10 film!

review: A return to form for this piracy centered franchise. Rob Marshall breathes life into a dead series with his swashbuckling adventure picture Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011). Borrowing heavily from the previous installments and Indiana Jones and The Last Crusade, Marshall takes us on a curious sea voyage seeking The Fountain of Youth and eternal life. Gore Verbinski's original Pirates of the Caribbean trilogy was much darker and more distinct, but Rob Marshall makes pretty well made films with a sleekness that's comforting. Johnny Depp is hilarious as the bumbling Captain Jack Sparrow, who improvises his way to victory with some clever wordplay and devious cunning. Geoffrey Rush's Captain Hector Barbossa is still fiercely entertaining with a raging vengeance sailing him towards Blackbeard. The gorgeous Pen√©lope Cruz is cool as a sword fighting love interest for Sparrow as the voluptuous and vexing Angelica Teach. She's a wonderful addition to On Stranger Tides and adds a formidable foil element to bounce comedy, romance, and swashbuckling off of Sparrow. Ian McShane has a gravitas as Blackbeard, but I wish he got more screen time. If his crew were not focused on so much, he could have fought and killed more as Blackbeard to make him more intimidating and scary into the dread pirate Blackbeard. Kevin McNally is still steadfast and funny as first mate Joshamee Gibbs. Sam Claflin is nice and charming as priest Philip Swift. His romantic affair with the enchanting French mermaid, played by the hauntingly lovely Astrid Berg√®s-Frisbey, is a nice side plot for On Stranger Tides. Richard Griffiths has a hilarious cameo as King George II. Keith Richards kills it again as Jack's father Captain Teague Sparrow. He's mysterious and entertaining, while providing a serious presence in his scenes. Dame Judi Dench gets a funny quick cameo as High Society Lady. Marshall knows how to direct interesting action sequences like the double duel or the mermaid encounter with intricate timing. Marshall is also competent at directing sincere drama, but he leans too heavily here into the hectic near improvised humor. I wanted more romance drama between Captain Jack Sparrow and Angelica as well as more character development for Blackbeard. Marshall's direction is engaging and slick enough to keep me easily entertained by On Stranger Tides' 136 minutes. It's more compact than previous movies with David Brenner and Wyatt Smith's editing is more forward thinking and efficient than the bloated jump cut riddled At World's End. Hans Zimmer returns to cascade us with epic classical music for his Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides score. Heavy strings and intense percussion mark his sonic style with beautiful compositions throughout On Stranger Tides. Penny Rose's period costumes continue to amaze me with realistic pirate outfits down to the floppy hats and boots. Ve Neill's make-up is still excellent as I still like his use of black eye liner and dirty looks for all the pirates. It's not perfect with Ted Elliott and Terry Rossio rely too much on past in jokes instead of new bits, plus Blackbeard's crew being zombies is dumb and has essentially already been done in The Curse of the Black Pearl. Elliott and Rossio create a mysterious atmosphere with their intriguing writing with plenty of fun humor and lighthearted action. Dariusz Wolski's cinematography features heavenly fountain wide shots to intense mermaids attacking from dark waters with striking shots. Wolski is a creative cinematography with a stalwart style for Pirates of the Caribbean. In conclusion, Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides is a refreshing splash of cold water to the face after the wayward and bloated At World's End.
mojo_name: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides

review: I had watched Despicable Me only so that I could finally understand what the whole deal with the minions was. But I ended up liking the movie and all the characters in that. As a result I decided to watch the sequel as well, which I ended up liking even more than the first one. So I thought why not just go all out and watch every single movie? And so I watched this one, and I really I think it was not something really great, although it did manage to do what it was meant to do: give us the laughs and have a good time. Despicable Me 3 is about Gru finding out about his estranged brother Dru who is living a very rich life but does not have the evil nature of Gru and thus is not liked as much by his family. And so grew is forced to take his brother along with him to stop the evil villain Balthazar Bratt, a child actor from the 80s who has faded away with time. Although the minions in this movie are way less than the previous two I don't mind this at all. In fact I kind of found them annoying and I wanted more of the human characters than those yellow Facebook meme sources. Balthazar is my favourite villain from this franchise. All his acts are very funny. Whenever he is on the screen you know you are in for some good time. There are often callbacks to his show which is very campy and has barred CGI according to today's times, which is just like how we see shows from the 80s today. He always dances and plays songs whenever he is out on the heist. It is fun to watch Gru and Balthazar fight in the opening scene and also the way Baltasar dances as he defeats all the guards on the ship. The animation of this movie is way better than the previous two, especially when it comes to the action scenes and car chasing. What this movie lacks in however, is the amount of campiness and cliched moments of having an amateur person come out on a secret mission along with the professional friend/family member. In fact the whole idea of the protagonist having an estranged twin brother is a cliched idea which has been used many times in Bollywood films. Although this isn't a very memorable movie, it does exactly what all the other movies from this franchise do. It is able to create a fantasy world with fun and loving characters who do goofy things and we enjoy them while it lasts. And this is the reason why I don't think this franchise should have more movies. By the time one movie comes we have already forgotten what happened in the previous one. Although I wouldn't say that this is a bad movie, I would definitely say that you would not remember anything other than the good parts once the movie ends, and this is the reason why this movie is so much fun to remember since I don't exactly remember what I didn't like about it.

review: I really enjoyed it Despicable Me 3 is my personal 2nd favorite in the series. There are parts of what made the first so amazing and each part shot into one of the sequels and I think Despicable Me 3 did its part better. The movie has only two major weaknesses that are easy to get past being that there is too many plots and that it relies on juvenile humor and toilet humor more than the last two. However, these are just small flaws and are easy to look past once you see the plots mesh together in a really satisfying way. This movie had some pretty good highlights, like when Gru said his mother told him that his father died of disappointment when he was born as well. Overall, Despicable Me 3 is an extremely enjoyable ride I'd recommend to anyone who can get past its flaws.

review: I behold to you‚Ä¶..the best Pixar sequel that isn't a Toy Story film! So I liked this movie a lot‚Ä¶.and that's pretty much it. I guess I could dive into all the things they changed. For example, because Dory is now the main character, Marlin and Nemo are sidelined. I don't see that as a problem with Nemo, because that's what happened in the first film. It's more Marlin that I'm disappointed in. He became just a meaner version of his character from the original sometimes, so I started to kind of dread when he came on screen. Next, all the new characters. Except for probably Hank, I don't think I'm going to remember them the same way I remember the side characters from the original film. Oh, and just to get it out of the way, voice acting and animation is once again spectacular. The setting feels like a new breath of fresh air too, with it being an aquarium. The story is pretty simple, but besides the two 5 out of 5 Pixar films this decade so far (Toy Story 3 and Inside Out), all of them have been pretty simple stories. I guess the one big problem that I have is that Dory's flashbacks are important and nice, but a little too convenient for the plot, and by the end, way too repetitive. Speaking of the ending, it's absolutely bonkers that a fish and a septopus can drive a truck, but I kind of love how crazy it is. Oh yeah‚Ä¶and this film has a big emotional moment, which the original, in my opinion, does not have. This is of course being when Dory is reunited with her parents. It's a chefs kiss of an emotional scene. So, is this film better than the original? No, I don't really think it's that close to be honest. But, is this a good film that I think everyone should watch! Hell ya! It has its problems, but they in no way ruin the film, at least for me. Go to Disney+ and watch this deep sea adventure, but they're not in the sea a lot, but still watch it!

review: Finding Dory was actually not that bad. I thought the story was touching of how Dory was finally able to see her actual family was pretty charming and heartwarming at times. However the only issue that I have with this movie is that it does feel long like the first one and some scenes could be cut out mostly some of the scenes between Nemo and Marlin because to me they felt like they were here just because they were here in the first movie. However with that being said though the movie is actually pretty interesting. I find it nice that for Dory we're getting more on her character than the first movie and this film does do a good job of making you care about the new characters that are in this movie. So overall this movie might not be as good as the first one but it is still an enjoyable ride. 7.8/10

review: Right from the beginning, this film is firing on all cylinders. It tugs on the heartstrings straight away and intermittently throughout the movie. It's a nice role-reverse on the ‚ÄòFinding' premise and the voice acting is top-notch from the characters old and new alike. The new characters, by the way, are easy to warm up to and easily fit into this world. The pacing of the movie is great end-to-end, and the intentions of each character are clear which makes the story easy to follow. It doesn't feel as grand as Finding Nemo but that change only makes this film feel more personal which fits the character and the story being told. This is a very poignant movie with wonderful characters and a worthy successor to the original film.

review: While it's nowhere near the magic of the original, Finding Dory is still a charming (albeit mostly safe) fun ride with a heartfelt message of empathizing with and empowering individuals born with disabilities. Dory's relationship with her parents in particular is really sweet. The new characters are charismatic in their own rights too. Unfortunately, Marlin and Nemo have been relegated to the sidelines with very little to do. But to be fair, their story arcs were already completed by the end of the original movie and admittedly this movie's focus is undoubtedly Dory's story to tell. Though I have to say, the climax is incredibly stupid and almost goes against the message of wildlife rehabilitation. But on the upside, the ending that follows it with Dory's reuniting with her parents certainly more than makes up for this. Not necessarily a Pixar classic, but certainly one worth your time.

review_date: A fun chronological start to the Star Wars Saga, Menace is exciting and has some decent moments here and there. Unfortunately, it has a lot of dead space, unnecessary dialogue, and a few unlikeable or downright laughable side characters. If you're new to Star Wars, watch this one after the original so you don't get turned off by how boring the series can be at times when it's world building the story.

review: With new characters, places, and things that are introduced, "The Phantom Menace" begins this prequel trilogy with a rocky start. The inclusion of some characters felt unnecessary to the plot, and the humor in this film is miles away from the witty humor that the previous films had. The CGI and action is a significant improvement in this film, with much more spectacle to the fights. There were some odd lines said in the movie, and I think some of the acting is extremely flawed. However, the villains are great and the vast number of Jedi introduced is not done in a way where its hard to remember the names. Overall, while the film does have its good parts, there are quite a number of bad parts when compared to the previous films and I can see why die-hard fans of the original trilogy continue to hate on this film, though I don't personally think its as bad as most people will say.
mojo_name: Star Wars: Episode I - The Phantom Menace

review: Despite the bland acting, I greatly enjoy watching this film. I grew up with it so I might be a bit biased, but overall the story itself blends well with the whole of Star Wars and is visually pleasing to see. It's got legendary music composed by the legend himself, John Williams, it introduces Darth Maul, and it exercises a wide range of revolutionary film tactics that were ahead of its time. For all of it's accomplishments and setbacks though, I ultimately give it this rating for how well it entertains me and for being a big part of my childhood. (P.S. I in no way endorse the midichlorian stuff. It's stupid.)

rt_name: Alice in Wonderland - Movie Reviews

review: This film is an amalgamation of Alice's Adventures in Wonderland and Through the Looking-Glass by Lewis Carroll with a tiny bit of the 1951 Disney film thrown into the filter of Tim Burton's direction. While I was excited to see Burton's version of Wonderland, the movie changed so much of the characters from the source material that it was not a movie about Wonderland. So much so that they changed the name of Wonderland to Underland. This film looks terrific, from the costumes Alice wears to the CGI. I also enjoy the story arc of Alice and the new character of Bayard. The rest of the characters are reduced to delivering exposition or short gags. If you would like to see a totally unique version of Lewis Carroll's works then check this movie out, otherwise skip it.
rt_name: Alice in Wonderland - Movie Reviews

review: This movie was visually entertaining but that was it for me. Just a lot of the same tired old hollywood tropes. The storyline didn't really make sense and so many lines that attempted to be heartfelt made me cringe. Although it attempted to be a feminist piece the narrative is so unbelievable in terms of gender norms of the period that this fantasy take feels like a mocking joke. I guess a period piece loosely based on Alice in Wonderland is another great excuse to employ an all-white cast and another skinny blond lead. Overall a shallow shiny package that failed to present anything genuinely meaningful or thought-provoking.
rt_name: Alice in Wonderland - Movie Reviews

review: First off, I want to state how boring this movie is. It has serious pacing issues with it moving so slow. Some of the scenes were stretched out for too long and include unnecessary dialogue and weird visual elements. For instance, the Futterwacken scene at the end of the movie is not funny and wastes time. I appreciate the call back to the actual book, but it's just not amusing to watch. This wasted time could have easily been put to good use in the final battle scene which is so anti-climatic. It's such a shame that we went on such a long journey through Wonderland just for the final battle to be only around 10 minutes with 2-3 minutes of that being the Jabberwocky battle. The story is also very poorly written. It all just falls apart after Alice makes her way into the Red Queen's castle. The whole "Um" bit is not funny whatsoever and is stretched out way too long. I know that Alice has grown and that whole aspect does make some sense. However, the Knaves of Hearts not noticing it sooner or pointing it out sooner made no sense and felt like just a lazy way to create the heist scene. A lot of the Red Queen's story is very poorly written which is such a shame because Helena Bonham Carter does a good job in the role. Speaking of the cast, it's a mixed bag. The voice cast does a nice job, but the on-screen talent is a little off. Both Johnny Depp and Mia Wasikowska have some nice moments, but their line delivery is off most of the time. As I said before, Helena Bonham Carter does a nice job as the Red Queen. Crispin Glover and Anne Hathaway do a decent job, but their roles feel more like parodies of the characters rather than them actually embodying the roles they were placed in. The world around these characters is really bad. The visuals are so bland and dark that it doesn't even feel like Wonderland. I get why Tim Burton would have made that choice as their lives are all kind of miserable at the moment, but even the flashback scenes look dull and unimaginative. I would have loved to have seen some more color pop off the screen when Alice defeated the Jabberwocky. I think it would have made the film's final scenes in Wonderland be more at a decent level rather than just outright bad. Overall, this film is just a big mess with poor editing, a below-average story, and a cast that doesn't quite shine. Tim Burton doesn't do anything outstanding and just feels like lazy directing and storytelling. When Tim Burton said he had never felt any emotional tie-in to the book, that should've been some major red flags that this film would not be good in any shape or form. Read more reviews like this at postcreditreviews.com
rt_name: Alice in Wonderland - Movie Reviews

review: Not a very good film, but let's use this as a platform to talk about Mercury Poisoning, shall we?* The term "Mad as a Hatter" came from a time when Mercury was used in the hat making process and people started going mad. What are common traits of Mercury Poisoning? Depression. Anxiety. Clumsiness. Hallucinations. Who was Mercury in mythology? The God of Thieves, and a messenger to Gods. What does Mercury hold in his hand? That is the Caduceus. That is Kundalini. That is the ancient brother-sister duo battling themselves; Fuxi and Nuwa. If we are all sitting at the table of the Mad Hatter, we are bound to have consumed his poison. So, when trying on different brands of hat, do remember the attached anxiety and depression is not hallucinated, but the preoccupation of all things related to Mercury... *Please consult Jeremy Piven for further research in these matters.

review: Famouse world classic story of Alice's Adventures in Wonderland being filmed again in Dark and Gothic theme named Alice in Wonderland. The plot is drastically changed from the original book, but it still have charm and uniqueness of story. Alice the protagonist of the story have grown up to a woman and forgotten Wonderland, she was expected to be someone she's not and still can't find her way. She is brought to Wonderland again by white rabbit according to the prophecy that ‚ÄòAlice' will slay Jabberwocky save but there's a question that ‚ÄòIs she the right Alice, the same one in the prophecy' and Alice also doubt that. Life of Alice is not smooth and Wonderland become a place full of danger but that's what make this movie interesting. Some characters are threaten, kidnapped, prisoned, and nearly executed but it's still in safe zone that people every age can watch together. In climax, Alice enter the war and slay Jabberwocky, fighting scene is not exciting and quite predictable for fantasy adventure movie with no fight experience woman protagonist but the war end beautifully. When back to her world, she returns as an elegant, brave and confident woman who walk in her own way. The background is mysterious but powerful and beautiful. Most characters are mystery and have their own charm, and I wish there's continue seasons.

review: Despite how serene the lead actress is and how competent the CGI is constructed, this might be one of the most unpleasant looking movies I have ever seen. Yes, it's Tim Burton so it's meant to be at least semi-repellent visually, but Tim Burton also relies almost entirely on his visual aesthetic, which makes this unpleasant aspect of the movie the central focus. What's unfortunate is that this was originally sold to many audiences as an Adaptation of the American McGee version, which already looks like a Tim Burton version, just better, with far, far better writing, so this would've been better. Instead, we're left with the kind of poor-to-abysmal quality script that seems to accompany most Tim Burton films, not only giving us wonky and sometimes incoherent storytelling, but even manages to mold the movie with almost every current-day Cinematic Fantasy Cliche, resulting in an Army vs Army battle with Alice as some kind of makeshift Valkyrie with a magic sword. There is good to be found -- Burton's usual use of slightly over-the-top performances complements this world as it's over the top in itself, Elfman turns in a surprisingly pleasant and epic score (considering all of his past scores for Burton films have just been off-key strings to make you feel icky and uncomfortable), and the art, while inherently repellent, is actually of solid quality for the most part; like, if I saw many of these on some place like DeviantArt I would think "That's pretty interesting" - the problem is that the movie never stops with it. It was a miscalculation to have the Evil Queen get so much screen-time as she is far and away the most visually unpleasant aspect of the movie, and the fact that the movie was made during the 3D boom means that she is commonly in ultra-closeup. And frankly, it just feels like Tim Burton isn't fitted to make a movie that is >90% CGI - he does have some talent with the tangible, physical world, and this movie makes me feel happy that he has opted to stay away from this kind of filmmaking since.

review: I went into this film without high expectations. I saw so many ways it could go wrong, and many of Burton's more recent films have left me feeling somewhat indifferent. However, all my fears were for naught. I adored the film, without reservation. Indeed, this is not only one of Burton's best films, it is probably the best screen adaptation of Lewis Carroll ever (with the possible exception of Jan Svankmajer's Neco z Alenky from 1988). It isn't often that a film ends and I immediately want to see it again, but that's how Burton's Alice in Wonderland affected me. The cast is flawless, top to bottom. The film's vision comes the closest anyone has come to capturing the frenetic, nonsensical impossibility of Wonderland (and I loved the whole "Underland" thing). I'm hearing all sorts of bizarre negative criticisms, though none with merit. This is a bold and triumphant film, one that finally addresses, without holding back, the darkness and complexity and maturity of Carroll's writing. I will add that I saw it in 2-D, and was pleased that Burton avoided letting the 3-D thing ruin the movie, as is so often the case with that sadly popular gimmick. The film is a giddy, hallucinatory, unrelenting dance of shadow and light, hilarious and heartbreaking, brash and underscored, possessed of all the marvelously contradictory oppositions that characterize the source material. For the first time, I think, it felt as though Alice were truly an integral part of the landscape, and not just some baffled Victorian tourist passing through. And the climactic battle with the Jabberwocky...just wow. I cannot recommend this film strongly enough. (--Caitl√≠n R. Kiernan)

review: In a large city populated by mammals of every sort, a bunny cop must team up with a street hustling fox to solve a missing mammal case. What makes this movie shine is the writing. Creating an allegory for racism between predators and prey works extremely well. The different boroughs of Zootopia to accommodate animals from different environments is creative. Jason Bateman and Ginnifer Goodwin work well together and the supportive cast is memorable in their own ways. This film is well put together, a new gem in Disney animation and a must watch.

review: This type of world building with character driven story is something you'd expect from Pixar at their brilliant best, but Zootropolis is Disney Animation's doing. The story itself is progressive in its outlook, a female bunny achieves her dream of becoming the first rabbit to become a police officer, but faces prejudice in every aspect of the job. Zootropolis has an excellent message at its heart, but it's also cleverly written and amusing, perfect to keep the kids (and adults) occupied during this summer holiday afternoon.

review: Summary: Judy Hopps dreams of leaving Bunnyburrow and becoming Zootopia's first rabbit police officer. Her first day on the job, she gets stuck with parking duty and gets duped by a sly fox. She hopes that one day she'll be able to fight real crime. Takeaways: In a world where prey and predators live harmoniously (well, mostly), the animal society still has stereotypes about the jobs each animal is meant for. A precious story about following your dreams with a spunky main character and many laugh-out-loud moments.

review: Thanks to Disney+ and an unlimited number of Disney movies at my fingertips, I was finally able to enjoy Zootopia last night. It was surprisingly a very adult-centric movie and for a while I even forgot I was watching a Disney cartoon. The animals portrayed had very emotional, real world human problems to overcome and guaranteed anyone who watched this movie can relate to one of them. Personally...I relate to the sloths. But on a more serious note, I am very pleased to have found out that a sequel will be released later in 2021 because these characters are just too good to be one and done then forgotten about.
