review: As a kid I hated Shrek. But after seeing it for the first time a few years ago, I decided that I really liked Shrek. I had to go on a vacation soon after finishing the first movie, so right after coming back I proceeded to watch the next one. And I think it's probably because of the trip or something, but I actually liked Shrek 2 more. There are many reasons why I feel this one is clearly superior to the first one, and why this is my favourite sequel among any movie (other than Lord of the Rings and The Dark Knight trilogies of course). The movie begins with the part where Shrek 1 ended. Shrek and Fiona are happily married and live their ogre lives in peace. The reason why this movie works so well is because unlike regular sequels, this one actually expanded on what could happen in future. If this was a conventional sequel it would have shown that Lord Farquaad has come back somehow and now he has joined forces with some other villain to beat them. Also some random characters would have been introduced while others would have been killed. The movie simply begins with the feeling of an adventure. Shrek, Donkey and Fiona going to Far, Far Away to meet Fiona's parents who have never seen her in the last 20 years, that's a perfect story. Remember how we thought about Shrek and Fiona before the first movie? We changed our minds for the better after we watched the movie and learnt a lesson. Fiona's parents, however, have still not seen that happen. And this is something Fairy Godmother and Prince Charming take the advantage of. The reason why this movie worked but the next two didn't was because this movie never dragged any concept. Shrek and the fairy tale characters became friends, Shrek and Donkey saved Fiona, they fell in love and married. Period. This was never 'revised' upon. Rather either the consequences of those actions or the other aspects of life were shown. Every scene looked interesting for some reason. It's almost like the creators poured all their love in every scene. No scene feels like they were just trying to get over it. Every moment is cherished: Fiona crying, Shrek meeting Puss, Shrek's friends watching TV - everything is memorable. Shrek 2 is how a sequel should be. It should give us exactly what we wish to know. It does not force any character, it does not force any scene. Everything that is introduced in this movie, every joke that takes place happens within the audience's interest. I really wish if a new Shrek movie is made, they make it like this. Shrek is meant to be something that is remembered for all time, not a meme. It's one of the most iconic 3D animated movies I've ever seen.

review: The story of Freddie Mercury is a tragic and hard-edged story about a immigrant gay man who did drugs and died of AIDS. The way this movie tells this story comes off as hollow and sanitised, there is so much inaccurate stuff in this movie like the fact that Queen broke up as a band because they were upset that Freddie Mercury got a deal for a solo album which upsets the band in the movie which never happened in real life because Roger Taylor released a solo album in the late 70s early 80s and in the movie Freddie Mercury tells the band he has AIDS a week before Live Aid in 1985 although he wasn't diagnosed until 1987. This is not the worst movie I have ever seen in my life but it's not exactly the greatest either
rt_name: Bohemian Rhapsody - Movie Reviews

review: An enjoyable film but one that never feels like it truly knows what it wants to be. Is it trying to make us marvel at the creative talents of Mercury, or feel unsettled and sad at his elusive, lonely personal life? Are we supposed to feel sympathy with the band who need to comply with his antics? Or take inspiration for how energised and on-board they are with his creative direction? The film flirts with the underlying tragedy of his private life and the illness that inevitably claims his life, but keeps it at arm's length to prevent the audience from getting sad when there's rock music to enjoy. So it's a good film but not an excellent one. Rami Malek is astonishing though, without question.

review: It isn't terrible, I guess. I like Queen's music. Why does this movie have auto tune and lip syncing over the original recordings and not new recordings by Rami Malek unlike Taron Edgerton in Rocketman. I think it is really funny that the members of Queen get mad because they have to lip sync on tv but then they lip synced all the singing in this movie. The editing in this movie is terrible. How did this movie win an Oscar for best editing? I do not understand. They always say that Freddie is drunk or high but they never show him getting drunk or high, unlike Rocketman. The best way to describe it is that this movie is very sanitized and safe. The movie doesn't go into the real side of Freddie at all. The movie is also not factually accurate. Freddie got diagnosed with AIDS in 1987 but in the movie he gets diagnosed before the Live Aid concert which was in 1985. Rami Malek's performance is pretty good though. I liked the lawyer/manager character. The music is great but that has nothing to do with this movie. I do really like the Live Aid scenes though. The Live Aid scenes are definitely the best part of the movie hands down. I just find the Live Aid concert really cool and fascinating. I also believe Live Aid was probably the best concert ever. The story, being a true story is pretty interesting so I liked the story told in the movie. In conclusion, John Reid is a terrible person, lip syncing is bad, this movie is disappointing and mediocre but not the worst movie ever by any means and Rocketman is way better. I will say Rocketman is so much better, it's not even a competition. Bohemian Rhapsody wishes it was even near as good as Rocketman.
rt_name: Bohemian Rhapsody - Movie Reviews

review: A biopic is a film meant to dramatize a non-functional person's life. Some creative license is used to provide exposition. Maybe some scenes are created to move the story along. This is not a biopic. Most of the movie is simply invented by the writers and director. For example, Freddie didn't meet the other band members behind a van after their show; they were already roommates. There was no backlash against the Bohemian Rhapsody song; everyone loved it at the start. The band wasn't inspired to perform at Live Aid by Freddie's courage in the face of AIDS; he wasn't diagnosed with that until two years after that show. The movie at all times is heading towards that Live Aid performance, which was recreated shot for shot with the original footage. This begs the question: why recreate what Queen did in 1985 with actors when you literally have the original footage?

review: A complete and utter waste of film to a band who more than deserves an insightful biopic, "Bohemian Rhapsody" merely reenacts concert scenes and studio work scenes with added Hollywood cliche tropes of romance in between. The sum of what's already available can inform fans beyond anything this piece of trite can muster. The cast is believable, but the direction is anything but.

review: [‚≠êÔ∏è97%] When the genre fantasy is mentioned, The Lord of the Rings is the first thought that comes to many peoples minds as it captures all the desired qualities required to be considered in that genre. The Fellowship of the Ring (2001) starts off the viewers experience with this trilogy in an absolutely outstanding way, leading from place to place, introducing things for the first time to the viewer along with the characters and never once failing to entertain. The reason for The Fellowship of the Ring (2001) being so engaging is that it follows such an engaging story with well developed characters, who all get their individual moments or in a group dynamic. Despite this films (and it's sequels) famous lengthy-runtime, it isn't felt compared to other movies as they provide a reason for using such length in executing engaging dialogue and a well thought-out story.

review: Peter jackson is one of the best directors in terms of good budget use, the director probably learned that in his early career directing great trahs movies, and in "The Lord of the Rings" it's no different, peter makes a film of almost 4 hours grand, with impeccable costumes and makeup, great visual effects for the time and a wide range of magnificent backdrops and screen compositions, by comparison, the same year also came out Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone which cost 38 million more, although "The Lord of the Rings" seems much more expensive. I didn't read the classic JRR Tolkien book to know how it was transposed to the screen, but even with a long film time, we have zero waste, we have a story that constantly grows, full of arcs and a past that transports mythology, all of this combined with a classic and very well constructed hero arc that unfolds in a great intro drama, the film has four acts and a short last act that already leaves a plot for the sequel. The entire art direction of the film is exquisite, the feature film, which is already over 20 years old, leaves some special effects dated, it's true, but at the time it was very surprising and still convinces today, especially in its costumes and makeup, which are still great today. , photography and the use of the green background still work reasonably well, and the soundtrack is a show on its own, showing the inner emotion of each nucleus through its melodies. Peter Jackson works well not only the visual and script factor, but also works the small layers, such as obsession, fear and overcoming, and also knew how to squeeze the most out of his cast of actors, taking magnificent performances, such as de Ian McKellen for example. The film is very well worked in its most diverse layers, every shot is very well executed and formidable, the weakest point perhaps is the lack of coherence, violence and the sobriety tone of the work, which changes its state of mind constantly, but these are details that do not bother this work at all, which amuses, entertains and enchants to this day. GRADE 8.5/10

review: Well... I'm afraid that this movie is by far the most disappointing film that I've ever sat down to watch. I came in with the greatest of expectations, as I've seen countless amazing reviews, articles, and even been directly told of the praise that this movie "deserves". How it's "better than the book", "truly riveting", "the greatest action movie to date", and so on. However, I simply cannot agree with any of those claims. I think Peter cheapened much of the story, even beyond that of what's expected from compressing 423 pages down to 178 minutes worth of film *I watched the theatrical version*. Since this review is already getting very long I'm going to list out the changes that Peter made that I think were for the worse. -Merry was re-written to become a Pippin part 2, which is especially terrible since in the original story they were quite different. Merry starts out responsible and leader-like then has to deal with feelings of loneliness and usefulness. While Pippin starts out naive and mistake-ridden then learns to become responsible and valiant. -Elrond and Galadriel are very dislikeable. I could smell their superiority complex through my screen. -Gandalfs already 'not perfectly' written pre-fellowship journey becomes even worse. Like why go to Saruman before safely escorting the Hobbit to Rivendell? Why not go help the Hobbit directly after getting to Rivendell? What happened to the letter? -Aragorn and Gandalfs relationship is too mysterious. You don't see them interact with each other much, Gandalfs speaks of no importance with Aragon, and all that makes Aragorn's presence at the prancing pony even more convenient. Furthermore, why weren't the Hobbits more suspicious of him when they met? -Nazgul nerfed? Why was Aragorn able to solo 5 of the Nazgul with nothing but a sword and torch? In the book, they quickly fled because they thought that Frodo had no chance at surviving the wound, but in the movie, they stayed to fight with Aragorn for a bit before getting chased out because Aragorn was destroying them. -The Gandalf v Saruman fight was maybe the worst fight scene I've ever seen from such a big movie. Force pushing each other around with sticks, how exciting. -Elves were just cringy, with the blurring filter and ugly language, it was just too much. -Legolas, Gimli, and Boromir were less explained. In the books Legolas comes to tell about Golums escape, Gimli comes to discuss Saurons offer to the Dwarves on the lonely mountain, and Boromir comes to find counsel on his and Faramir's dreams. But in the movie, they are just there because they are important figures in their kingdoms. Although I have plenty of gripes with the movie I think it still did a fine job. I thought the production quality was outstanding, even for 2021's standards. I also like that Arwen became more prevalent in the story, although her being the one sent to help Aragorn and the Hobbits makes no sense but exploring her and Aragorn's relationship early on was a definite plus to the story. So overall I don't think it's bad but it stacks nowhere near the original story and I can't believe that anyone can say otherwise, but I seem to be in the minority so maybe I'm just wrong.

review: There are a lot of neat concepts on display in this movie, and as such, it's a real shame that more aren't done with them. This movie is 157 minutes long, and only the last 10 minutes actually amounted to anything. The rest of it is a self-contained story that has very little in the ways of actual plot, and the big reveal at the end ultimately negates half of what came before, as it turns out that a good chunk of it was a ruse (but not in the ultra-satisfying way as something like Hot Fuzz or the first Saw). Throw in the fact that the movie is also darker and murkier than the other entries, before and since, and the very mediocre performance by Robert Pattinson (already one of the most over-valued people in the industry). The mystery element involving David Tennant's character, Harry Crouch Junior, is really the only thing of real interest beyond the end, but it never actually amounts to anything either, as the audience already knows that he's evil, and once he's found out, his story ends literally seconds later.. All in all, the movie isn't 'bad' by any means - it's just almost entirely meaningless in the grand scheme of things, and honestly, it's just self-indulgence that this movie was a solid hour longer than it needed to be.

review: Imperio‚Ä¶ Crucio‚Ä¶ Avada Kadavra‚Ä¶ now time to go to Azkaban. So there's more than one wizard school. The plot is about the Triwizard tournament, where each school's representative battled for the glory. But somehow Potter was chosen as the fourth contestant, and we have ourselves a fun and intense story. I was surprised and happy that I wasn't bored through another two and a half hours of this franchise. This is the first one that kept my interest throughout. Again, there were more unique wizard stuff that further expanded the universe. This was always fun to watch, and this movie still kept that tradition going. The first half actually was teen drama where the students went to a ball. The romance was more prominent, and even became naughty in some scenes. What drove the plot was the tournament, and the looming danger that hid beneath it throughout the runtime. When the imminent doom hit at around the last round of the tournament, the movie became vastly more intense. For the first time, I felt that Harry's life was in actual danger. As for problems, the runtime was still a tad bit long. Also, some of the rounds in the tournament were pretty weak an could have been more fun. Overall, this movie is where the main story actually starts. 9/10

review: Newell did more things right here than Cuaron did with the third movie and it's not even close. He makes the most out of the lengthy runtime here by excising a lot of the subplots in the novel in an extremely successful way as it allowed more time to be spent on the climactic finale than had been allotted in any of the previous 3 movies. There was more interaction between the characters and a highly appreciable increase in comedy. The actors had grown up quite a lot and were doing better in each iteration at showing their acting range, with Hermione a particular highlight in this one. Doyle acquitted himself remarkably well, with his film score on par with Williams's previous three and the CGI had improved drastically even with only a year's time passing. Best of all was the source material itself as the underdog sports genre is probably my #1 favorite and the finale here is probably the best in the entire series, both the graveyard part and the quasi-epilogue reveal. I think Cuaron misunderstood the intended audience for these as his priorities seemed rooted solely in quality filmmaking instead of entertaining a mostly-teenaged audience, a concept Newell is apparently an expert at. The only criticism I have is that I think they could've found a few minutes to devote to the Quidditch World Cup instead of skipping the entire thing as that was one of the best chapters in the book!

review: The non-so magical review from a muggle. Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire is a fantasy/adventure film directed by Mike Newell. It is based on J.K.Rowling's novel which was written in 2000 and carries the same name as the novel. It was released on November 23, 2005. It is as well the fourth part in the Harry Potter film series. Last Christmas, I saw this film and it was definitely one to remember. Just like past Harry Potter films this one didn't fail to amuse me. You could tell that this was filmed on a big-budget compared to the previous films of the series. To my mind I think this one offers a lot more than fantasy or adventure, it also gives you a lot of headspace to imagination. This piece of art surely left me astonished and filled with questions, wanting to watch the next part. As for the plot of Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire, it includes the three main characters to be grown up, as they enter their fourth year of the School of Wizardry and Witchcraft: Hogwarts. It holds a fair amount of violence, since Harry Potter, the main character has to enter the prestigious Triwizard Tournament as a minor and face some dreadful challenges along the way of becoming a champion. Throughout the film, new characters came to light. Some added a romantic aspect to the film, whereas others did not. For the 14-year-old Harry Potter, he endures pressure a normal teenager cannot handle to confront his biggest nightmare. With the help of his dearest friends, Hermione and Ron, he doesn't fail to succeed in the period of the tournament. After all, this is the year students prepare for the Yule Ball and dare to ask female students as their date to the ball. Yet, the charming part of the film quickly ends there, as Harry Potter will live up to his title as ‚ÄòThe Boy Who Lived'. The Harry Potter series is known to leave every person astounded who is into fiction and/or fantasy. As for me, it was always a surprising experience watching through these films, as you notice the characters growing up from a young child to an adult. There is no doubt that J.K. Rowling is by far one of the most influential writers in our century. Not only, did she write several successful books but stands as a role model for young children and women. With the apparent cliffhanger at the end of the first film, it will leave you wanting more and you will end up watching the next films that follows up on the previous one. Personally, I am a lover of anything fictional, which is obvious why I am a fan of Harry Potter. Behind the success of these series, I suppose that watchers admire the films as they are not predicable as much as you think it would be. For instance, in this film, it gets quite dark quickly once you watch Harry get involved into life-or-death situations. Another example, is that Harry experiences tons of emotions in this film. As he goes through happy moments with his friends, he goes through the same amount of unknown moments and feelings. However, I must say that this is perhaps the most significant Harry Potter film so far. Mainly because, while I was watching this part of the series it felt like a mix of genres. Also, another example to why this film doesn't have a sole boring moment since it will keep introducing new characters throughout. For the Triwizard Tournament I mentioned earlier, there will be a ton of new, yet interesting characters added who bring a value to these films, which also was an enjoyable aspect. Lastly, this film was not excessively long but definitely long enough to tell the story. But there is one negative detail, that the films don't fully cover every single detail like the books do. So if you want to have a full understanding experience, I suggest you to also read the books so that you don't miss out on other details. Clearly, this masterpiece will be a hard one to forget, as it will stick to you for a longer time. It is not something that you will be able to forget soon, as it so famous. I would recommend this film to anyone who might be interest in fantasy and fictional characters. Furthermore, it is important to watch them in chronological order, since every film leaves a cliffhanger at the end which follows up on the next one. Lastly, I hope you get lost into the imagination of the magical world of Harry Potter, just like I did.

review: Summary: This movie marks an important cornerstone in the development of the Harry Potter universe with the return of the Dark Lord Voldemort. It is set in Hogwarts during the fourth year of school, when the Triwizard Tournament takes place. It is a traditionally a competition between the three prominent schools of magic including Hogwarts, Durmstrang and Beauxbatons. Prior to the competition, the Goblet of Fire selects three students from each school to participate in the contest. Harry is unexpectedly selected and forced to enter the competition by the Goblet of Fire with three other students even though he never put his in the cup and he is also underage. Later, it is found out that one of the Voldemort's underlings cast an advanced spell on the Goblet to deceive it of Harry's age. During the first three rounds of the contest, Harry and the other students have to complete many difficult tasks such as rescuing underwater and fighting dragons. The climax of this movie comes when the four students compete to get out of the maze, the last round of the contest. However, Voldemort, still in his feeble from between dead and alive, and his underlings are in there waiting for the four, eventually killing Cedric from Hogwarts. Harry, after that, is capture, and his blood extracted and used to rebuild Voldemort into a strong physical form. Harry then duels against the Dark Lord for his life. He barely escapes Voldemort and eventually brings Cedric's body back to campus with the knowledge that Voldemort has returned. Analysis: The important turn of events in this movie heralds major change development of the storyline and the journey of Harry Potter as the main hero in this series. Harry is now no longer inherently safe from Voldemort like before when Harry's blood was has the magic against the Dark Lord. Now, both share the same blood as he used his Voldemort used Harry's blood to revive himself. Harry no longer is protected and now susceptible. He is now more representative of real-life heroes, who actually have vulnerabilities, not inherently indestructible by enemies as Harry used to be earlier in the series. This sharing of blood between Harry and Voldemort is also symbolistic of the struggles that real-life heroes have. It is like a connection across the dichotomy of good and evil, signaling the heroes also have their own evil side that they struggle against. Furthermore, when Harry's friend Ron turns against him, it further depicts Harry as a misunderstood hero. Ron estranged himself from Harry because Ron thinks that Harry intentionally enters himself into the contest for fame. However, later in the movie, Ron actually helps Harry to get through one of the dangerous rounds of the contest where the four students had to compete underwater. Ron's actions actually saved Harry's life. This part of the stories highlights the resilience of true friendship. No matter how significant the misunderstanding is, true friends will still help each other when in need and resolve the problem between them. Then when the four enter the last round of the tournament, the maze, Cedric encounters a minion of Voldemort, he is murdered by the killing curse. Then, Harry is captured by the other underlings of Voldemort. His arm is cut, and his blood collected to revive Voldemort. Harry has to duel against him for his life. He almost loses against the newly rejuvenated and strengthened Dark Lord. However, the souls of Harry's loved ones who were murdered by Voldemort appear from Voldemort's wand and give Harry's time to get to the Portkey to escape the maze. This scene demonstrates the theme of love's triumph over hate and evil. Critique: I love this movie and the whole Harry Potter series as a whole. There are, nonetheless, certain details that I think can be improved upon. The first one is rather a minor detail. It is when Dumbledore finds out the Goblet of Fire has chosen Harry as the fourth selectee to enter the tournament. The book says that Dumbledore ‚Äòcalmly' asks Harry if he actually put his name into the Goblet. However, the corresponding scene in the movie portraits Dumbledore's asking as aggressive and intimidating when he grabs Harry's arms and shakes them while questioning him. This minor detail, although does not affect the structural integrity of the storyline, somehow momentarily breaks the usual portrayal of Dumbledore as a gathered and calm man without serving any significant purpose. The second detail is when Harry is forced to enter the Tournament. J.K Rowling here could have better explained why it is that way, because the audience may have questions such as the following: Why is an underage forced to enter such a perilous contest even when he does not want to? Or Why can't/doesn't the administration do anything to keep Harry from the having to enter? Explanations to these questions can further strengthen the integral structure of the storyline. Overall, despite these small details that may be improved, I still give the movie 5 out of 5 stars.

review: The worst movie out of the trilogy, but really over hated. The reasons why people hate this movie is understandable, Peter Parker seems to have regressed on his love life which was developed and was seemed to be great as how the second movie ended, but in this film Peter Parker makes some decisions that make him a bad person when it comes to love and makes Mary Jane Watson feel not feel appreciated. Mary Jane Watson story is really not that good in this film they make her really dependent of a guy which in the comics, video-games, and TV shows/cartoons Mary Jane has always been an independent woman that takes care of herself most of the time. Villain wise this movie is also mid, out of the 3 villains, we only had one going into detail of why he was bad and why he took some decisions that made him a villain but only one had great character development and that was Sandman, for the other villain (New Green Goblin) we have had a background story of why he became a villain since the first film but to be fair they did do a good gob towards the end when it comes to that character. The main villain and the worst one is Venom, man came out of nowhere and managed to get into Peter Parker's apartment so easily without him realizing. Venom was a rushed character in this film, no background, man just landed on Earth from space and he only turned Peter Parker more into an anti-hero when Peter was his host but no interactions between Peter and Venom, also something to add, Venom turned into a suit which Peter easily took off and when Peter realized what was happening to him with Venom he struggles to take off his suit, makes no sense to me unless Venom realized Peter wanted him away so he just tried to stay with him. Once Venom reached Eddie Brook, it was more comic accurate but still a wasted villain nothing compared to the new Venom movies we have today. This movie is enjoyable but it is average at best compared to the other films.
rt_name: Spider-Man 3 - Movie Reviews

review: A massive disappointment compared to the classic first two, "Spiderman 3" has a much shakier and convoluted story that tries to cram too much into its short runtime. The action is still pleasant, though the CGI somehow feels worse than the previous films. The villains are still good and memorable, though there are just too many to give any of them their time to shine. The direction that this film heads in is also very confusing, rewriting some important plot points and actions of the previous two films. Maguire, Dunst, and Franco are still very well in this movie though, and the acting of the villains is also on point. There are also a number of entertaining sequences, though most get overshadowed by the large amount of cringey and unnecessarily bad moments that make no sense. Overall, just a bad film that fails to conclude the ending that the previous installments deserved.
rt_name: Spider-Man 3 - Movie Reviews

review: The trilogy ends on a confusing note. It's a really hard film to follow, there is so many stories here and all of them seems underdeveloped. The characters development which was what I preferred in the first two movies, doesn't feel relatable anymore outside few moments (most of the time during the scenes with Aunt Jay, the voice of reason). The big point of the movie was adapting the Venom arc, and the movie fails in every way. Venom feels very secondary, I would even say that if you remove everything about him the movie would be as "coherent" that it is. I know it's "iconic" now in a too bad is good kind of way, but for me the Peter Parker/Venom scenes was a secondhand embarrassment. I felt bad for the characters and I even felt bad for Tobey Maguire having to play these scenes. It's simply cringe. The special effects sometimes feel too ambitious for the time, they go overboard with the action scenes giving you tense moment but very noticeable green screens or CGI. It was a time where we qualify action movies as CGI messes and Spider-man 3 is the perfect example. The end is a little too cheesy and too easy.

review: I don't think there is a person out there that believes this is the best film in the trilogy. While it turns Spider-Man in a direction that I don't particularly like, I still find that this film shows some of the charm of the first two. I can tell this film was made with care and love, but I can also tell that the studio got their hands on it and turned, what I'm sure was a great plan from Sam Raimi, into a mess of too many villains and plots. I would have love to have seen a movie with Just Harry as the Green Goblin or Just the Sandman. I don't like the inclusion of Venom in the slightest, to me, Toby's Spider-Man is supposed to be a great lighthearted guy, the ultimate nice/good guy, and I loved that. But, the symbiote turns Toby into a dark individual that I don't think fits the series. For example, The Spider-Man from the 90's animated series was a great Spider-Man to use the symbiote with. While he was a great guy, and one of my favorite Spider-Men ever, he wasn't the ultimate nice guy that Toby's Spider-Man was on the big screen. They used the symbiote much earlier in his arc, season 1 of a 5 season show, at a time when he was still arrogant and immature, as opposed to a Spider-Man who had already progressed through 2 films. The version of Spider-Man in the animated series was much more self-centered and was a much better match for the symbiote. Overall, I like this movie, but I don't like Peter for some of it, and a can't help to think what could have been.

review: Honestly this movie isn't nearly as terrible as a lot of people claim - it's just a movie where the desires of the talented filmmakers were overridden by those of an executive. Primarily, Sam Raimi, the brilliant filmmaker who made the first two (in addition to the wonderful Evil Dead trilogy) did not want to make a Venom movie, as he considered Venom a boring villain, but the studio forced his hand to do it anyway. And as such, this is a movie made by instruction, made be a director that made the preceding entries out of passion. Combine this with some numerous production complications and self-proclaimed genius Danny Elfman refusing to write the music because he felt Raimi didn't appreciate his unbridled genius, and you've got a movie with massive, massive problems just due to happenstance. And it's actually rather sad, as much about the movie actually works very well -- The climax is hugely entertaining and ends with a moment of resolve, rather than defeat, the way Peter finally stands against Harry are actually quite cathartic, and the new Composer's musical score is much better than the forgettable-at-best fluff that we got from the previous two movies (as let's be real - the wonderful main theme was the only piece of music from the first two movies worth listening to). There's some efficient (yet widely misunderstood) comedy bits in this movie, and it is interesting to see not only Parker himself becoming increasingly violent, but one of the main villains increasingly, of his own accord, becomes a more and more volatile person, making him a good villain. If you loved the first two I'd ultimately recommend this one - the only real reason I hesitate is that there are some depressing "my dreams never came true" beats that come up during the story, but so long as you acknowledge that it's not nearly as good.

review: To be honest, surprisingly, Spider-Man 3 is my favourite from Tobey Maguire's trilogy. Tobey Maguire is still a bad actor, he and Kirsten Dunst still don't have romantic chemistry, but she improved as an actress. Despite the cast (the only good actors are Rosemary Harris, JK Simmons and James Franco), the villains are good. There is more action in this movie than in the other two combined, and I loved it because Peter Parker's arc was something I always felt bored watching. And this film is more than an emo Peter Parker. This emo Peter makes sense, I finally managed to have empathy for the protagonist, and the conclusion is perfect and touching. I ended the film proud of Peter. Finally, if I said the first film isn't that good, and the second one is good but overrated, this third one is underrated and deserves more than a "cult" status.

review: The final installment in Sam Raimi's Spider-Man trilogy in which Peter Parker bonds with an extraterrestrial symbiote that increases his abilities but brings out his anger and other negative traits. He also has to deal with Sandman, New Goblin and Eddie Brock and maintain a fragmented relationship with Mary Jane. Undeniably, the film is overstuffed with villains and plotlines that make it a bit too much. The fights and action sequences are very entertaining and well executed, though. Some scenes and dialogues are so cringeworthy that it pales in comparison to the first two.
rt_name: Spider-Man 3 - Movie Reviews

review: At the onset of his third big-picture treatment, we find young Peter Parker in an unfamiliar predicament: he's genuinely happy! Almost annoyingly so, in fact. Even his longtime love interest, Mary Jane Watson, seems to think he's laying it on too thick and tries to tell him as much in a series of awkward, abbreviated conversations between crime-fighting bouts. Parker pays no mind, of course, produces a string of awful motivational speeches when she needs emotional support and swiftly swings himself straight back onto the singles scene. Well, that didn't take long. Now Spidey is sad again! Just in time to tangle with three(!) competing super-villains, a rival in the workplace and a major league identity crisis. Not unlike its predecessors, Spider-Man 3 has way too much going on, a problem that's ballooned with each subsequent installment. The first two films manage to succeed in spite of this weakness, persevering with a great shared cast, strong character moments and well-earned payoffs. In those films, Pete's best pal Harry Osborn slowly works his way through a patient, simmering villainous turn. Here, he's abruptly hot-shotted in the opening action scene, carelessly reset and cast aside until the finale. Venom is birthed and dispensed in less than an act. Sandman's arc has enough emotional heft to single-handedly carry the counter narrative, but he always feels like a third wheel. Gwen Stacey pops in and out of the frame at random. There's just no room for these subplots to breathe amidst all the frantic competition, the race to grab every last thread and hurriedly weave them into something loosely resembling a story. Maybe with a touch of nuance and panache, a skilled director could have worked a little magic and turned this troubled script into an acceptable early-period superhero flick. Sam Raimi is anything but a nuanced director. At best, he's capable but limited, habitually caught in the act of winking at his own shortcomings in uniquely entertaining ways. No wonder he's best regarded for his gleefully deranged horror movies, where over-stressed people behave irrationally (and a little comically) in high-pressure situations. Under ideal circumstances, he can incorporate his eccentricities into the fabric of a film without negatively affecting its story, but not with so many other jobs on his plate. I'm not sure if the hammy over-acting is his fault or the stars', but I tend to lean toward the former because it's so hopelessly widespread. Nothing feels natural in this film, from the janky dialogue and clumsy delivery to the rushed primary character arc and dated special effects. I can still remember how this felt in the theater, bad enough that I avoided revisiting it for nearly fifteen years, and it hasn't improved with time. I can see bits and pieces of promise dotted here and there, hints that the overachieving Spider-Man 2 wasn't just a fluke, but they're drowned by the hurry to expand an already-crowded universe and get everything back to an unconvincing status quo in time for the closing credits. Disastrously inept.

review: In many ways, Spider-Man 3 is structurally the same as its two predecessors: Peter starts out the movie as Spider-Man and the villains, who aren't inherently villains, become so as the movie progresses. The biggest difference this time is that there are two villains rather than one and Peter plays a big part in why the villains are fighting him. In many ways, this same structure works to the film's benefit and gives us some interesting characters and nice action sequences. It's another example of if a system isn't broken, don't fix it. SM 3 also adds a lot of depth to Peter's relationships with those around him, which becomes especially important as Peter changes throughout the film in pretty drastic ways that have big consequences for him. SM 3 is a movie that exemplifies that concept that you can be your own worst enemy. The acting is pretty good overall, although there is a casting choice that to this day I'm not a big fan of. The effects in the movie have slightly raised the bar from the previous films, making this a slight improvement from SM and SM 2. All that said, SM 3 is a bit of a letdown and isn't as good as the other two. Many scenes lack the directorial and written finesse than they had in the first two which causes some scenes to feel really awkward and a bit disruptive to the flow of the film. The dialogue is a bit cheesy at times and there are some scenes that don't make a lot of sense. Sandman and Venom are decent villains but they aren't quite as good as Green Goblin and Doc Ock were, which is partially because they come from different plotlines so there isn't as much time to develop their characters as there would optimally be. One of the biggest issues of SM 3 is exactly that: there are a bunch of storylines going on at once so the movie doesn't have a clear and direct focus for a lot of its runtime, so certain things don't get the development they deserve. The film balances all these stories as well as it can and overall does a decent job, but there are things that could've been explored a bit more. The ending has an emotional punch to it to nicely caps off the trilogy and should leave viewers satisfied enough as the credits roll. SM 3 is undoubtedly a letdown from its two predecessors but is a decent enough movie to be watchable and enjoyable at times.

review: DOTD was when the series started to kinda-sorta slip out of its original brand, most of the movie is awesome, just like the last two, the saviors are raunchy humor and innuendo in a lot of cases, but again it's varied enough that adults AND kids can like it. This movie though you can start to smell it on the wind. It's entertaining for adults too, but it's just a little... more kid leaning, subtly, you won't realize it for a bit, but it's there. Ice Age would've been better off retaining its adult-oriented story devices, and the addition of legitimate death in the first one actually dramatically improved the series' quality while it was happening, you need some darkness to make things really acceptional in today's market.

I recommend Casino Royale, Skyfall and No Time To Die when it comes to a typical binge on the Daniel Craig Bond movies and recommend Quantum Of Solace and SPECTRE just once. rt_name: Spectre - Movie Reviews

review: Spectre is an entertaining and overlong spy thriller. Although it fails to reach the heights of Casino Royal or Skyfall- Spectre is a watchable, and often quite fun Bond movie. The action is great, cinematography is beautiful, performances are generally good, but the writing is fairly sloppy. Trying to have Blofeld become the one behind all of Bond's previous troubles is clearly retconning- and doesn't work great. Having Blofeld be Bond's jealous step-brother is just plain stupid- how would Bond not recognize someone he grew up with? The pacing is also a big problem. The opening is great with an amazing tracking shot followed by great action. In the middle act things slow down considerably, and the story isn't engaging enough to warrant it. Then the final act tries to squeeze in too much, and despite some great action it is jarring the way things jump from one event to the next so abruptly. It waits until the last 40 minutes to finally reveal the villain and have him interact with Bond- then we get an extended monologue, torture scene, and escape scene within a less than 20 minutes or less. The way Bond goes from having his brain scrambled to moments later being a deadeye shot, blowing up the entire base and escaping- is just silly and shows how carelessly some of the sequences were put together. There are a handful of other times where the logic just doesn't add up. Walken delivers a very hammy performance as Blofeld, a totally cartoonish villain when compared against previous Craig- Bond villains. All that said- this is a Bond movie with lots of style, great action, exotic locals, beautiful women, wonderful camera work, and a solid central performance by Craig (who is easily my favorite Bond).

review: Ah yes, the one that thinks it's Captain America: The Winter Soldier, but is actually Austin Powers in Goldmember. This is definitely a goofy Bond movie masquerading as serious one. I actually watched this twice in the theatres when it came out. That's how much I loved it at the time. I now know I was forcing myself to accept the glaring awful writing. I never particularly liked the writing even back then, but justified liking it for other aspects like directing, cinematography, musical score, action set pieces, and having the best costume design in the series. That last one I still believe. Just like how the jarring editing in tandem with poor blocking weighs the overall quality of Quantum of Solace down, so too does the writing of Spectre. Skyfall had some ridiculous plot holes as well but there were other aspects of the writing keeping it from being a totally trash script unlike this one. Thomas Newman's score is even better than I remember. I think I might even prefer it to his Skyfall score. However, the cinematography is way worse. For some reason I thought the super saturated sepia filter was present only in the cold open in Mexico, which would be bad enough, but it's like that throughout the film. Not a fan ever usually of sepia and here its at a whole other tier. I do really like Bautista's character. One of my favourite henchman honestly. The Austin Martin DB10 is one of my favourite Bond cars ever. It's number one of the modern cars (modern equals Brosnan and Craig eras). The car chase in Rome is decent, not as bad as some die hard fans say it is. I liked it. I would have preferred Rome be in winter to somewhat try to justify the lack of traffic. There definitely were some vehicles in the way, but perhaps not enough. Back to the writing. The C stuff that M is dealing with makes no sense. Dont they already have information on everyone? What exactly is going to change with having more of it? The Blofeld stuff makes absolutely no sense. Brothers? Seriously? not only is that bad by itself, it makes the world of of the entire series so much smaller. Bond also has to deal with him on his own by the end. Where is the rest of all his minions? and why in the old MI6 building? How did Bond shoot down a plane with a pistol (ok that one I always had a problem with, but now with everything else, it just feels even worse. When were they (Bond and Madeline) falling in love exactly? Because it wasn't in this movie. Speaking of which, never in this series have I seen more nonsensical reasons for having sex since The Man with the Golden Gun. Neither times did it feel appropriate. One of them was done for laughs and I wasn't laughing. some jokes actually do work though, the writing isn't absolute garbage. I like Q and a lot of his lines, most of the time. I like the Sam Smith theme song less and less every time I hear it. When it first came out, I loved it, was in my top 5 of all Bond themes. By now it's somewhere close to the bottom 5 for me if not already there. The graphic of the theme song is probably even worse honestly. Some weird shadows over people's faces going on. The cold open isn't even as great as I remember. No only is the sepia filter so overbearingly distracting, the first cut from the long take happens at a pretty random and awkward moment.

review: Spectre continues the story of Daniel Craig as James Bond and unfortunately is not one of the strongest instalments of this franchise. In here James Bond is tested by one of its toughest opponents yet Ernst Blofeld played by Christoph Waltz who is set to take over all the intelligence agencies of the world and make the world bow to him through an organization called Spectre. Craig here continues to kick ass and in here is struggling with the passing of M as played by Judy Dench. Now the mantle is taken over by the great Ralph Fiennes who is not as caring as Dench's M but is more stern and direct and gets in more sparring moments with Bond. The meat of the story though is the '' Bond Female'' played by the great French actress Lea Seydoux of Blue is the Warmest color fame. This is the best female character for this franchise since Casino Royale and establishes a romance that has great consequences for the story. Unfortunately even with Sam Mendes back as director this movie pales in comparison to Skyfall. Is convoluted with a very long dull pace and despite the great performance by Waltz this villain is quite disappointing with a very disappointing climax. This film could have been so much better

Blofeld, played by Christoph Waltz, is kinda wasted in the movie, which is disappointing because Waltz is such a masterful actor and he could have had a much larger presence in the movie. Overall, Spectre is a decent movie in the Bond franchise but it could've been so much more.

review: Spectre is satisfactory with a lot of elements that hold up throughout the whole film. Yet, several components get lost in the story that is not to the capacity it should be at. The story is flawed and does not flow right. This problem is apparent in the character arc of the villain. Just like Quantum of Solace, Spectre handles its villain terribly. Ernst Stavro Blofeld's story is so muddled with very little explanation. There is a lot of verbal exposition, but never any visual storytelling. Blofeld's storyline is a victim of this problem as the film had a near 150-minute screen duration yet can not show any relevant information. However, the film can get one of the Bond girls right and not just have L√©a Seydoux be the sexual one-off that Monica Bellucci is. Speaking of Bellucci, she is part of a weak opening. Bellucci should have never been in the movie since her character is a misfire. Spectre is the fourth film in this version of the franchise, and the filmmakers should know that they need to treat their characters better. The film also has a mixed bag in the technical aspects of the film. The cinematography is bland, with hardly any shots that are visually appealing. The film uses the hand-held camera too much and focuses on the wrong details. One of those two problems is more at the fault of Sam Mendes as his directing is a step-down from Skyfall. Mendes does not fulfill the concept and story of this movie in an orderly fashion. There are various moments in the film where it feels like a parody of a Bond movie that you would see on a sketch show. The cast is at fault here with some weak performances from multiple actors. Daniel Craig is at his lowest point in Spectre with a very emotionless performance. Craig delivered this fun cockiness in the other films, but here he exhibits a bland personality. Christoph Waltz is solid, yet it is hard to see the range of his character when Waltz has very little screen time. L√©a Seydoux is also a decent actor in the ensemble, and it was nice to see that she had a strong sense of emotion in times of uncertainty. Dave Bautista is a prominent addition to the cast and adds some much-needed variety to the film. Ben Whishaw is a delight in the role Q, yet he was missing that spark that he had in Skyfall. Lastly, there is Ralph Fiennes. Fiennes is excellent as M, and it was nice to see M expanded on with Fiennes making him a more likable character. Spectre is a misfire in the James Bond franchise, yet does have a few redeeming qualities in some of its departments. The story has a few bumps, and Sam Mendes is not doing the best work he can. However, Spectre is watchable as that is one highlighting aspect with any of these James Bond movies. Read more reviews like this at postcreditreviews.com

review: Like Quantum Of Solace, this is a film that is destined to suffer by virtue of being a sequel to its predecessor; in this film's sake, to possibly the best Bond film of them all. Once again like Quantum of Solace, this film benefits from revisiting long after initial release; though the action sequences and the over-arching plot are closer to the entertainingly over-the-top traditions of much earlier in the series, this is never over-egged. The balance is in fact just about right, and there are moments of direction and design that provide a visual impact that's quite unlike much I can remember in any other film in the series. It is too long - when Bond says 'this isn't over yet just' before we cut to the film's denouement from what we all expected to be the denouement when we saw it first time around, it's tempting to find yourself saying 'Really?'. The 4 (or will it be 5?) film arc of the plot requires this extra ending and whilst it does mean the film outstays its welcome a little, it's an undeniably well-executed final finale. That there are at least 2 Daniel Craig Bond films better than this (I'm writing this before seeing No Time To Die) could sound like a criticism, but on its own terms and with the benefit of time, this is a comfortable success.

review: Imagine a studio has a hot streak, it ain't broke, so they fix it. What do they fix it with? They decide "what if we do a remake of the WORST 'Scream' film?" and I actually LIKE Scream 3! At least it did those twists first as well as other ideas that were fun. It's not a great film, but I'd argue better than this one. Worse yet, this film is overlong and slow as sin. There's a couple of good action sequences, the cast is good, and treating it's female lead as more than it's male leads disposable condom are all great. The cinematography is decent too, but all this is wasted with the stupid twist done decades earlier and better in the film mentioned earlier, as well as a tendency to become formulaic, which HORRIFIES me. I HATE what this movie does to this movie's villain. It's too nostalgia-baity and pandering. I give this a 4/10. I'm scared No Time To Die might be just as unoriginally stupid from what I've heard. Fingers crossed that those people were lying or that movies' gonna suck. And I love Sam Mendes, Cary Jori Fukunaga, and Danny Boyle as directors! I think Skyfall is the best Bond film, but Specter might be one of the worst.

review: I will admit that they should have clarified the machine scene near the end more but my god I loved this movie. Otherwise, the action was great, the humor was on point, and the Spectre organization was ominous as fuck. Bautista, while not really being a character, is super badass. I really loved the movie, only slightly behind Skyfall because of Javier Bardem, the opening sequence of Skyfall being so amazing, and Skyfall's Home Alone on steroids final battle. But, once again, an amazing action movie.

Everything about this film just falls flat, given the high ambitions of the plot, it all feels very mediocre and dull, with the Blofeld plot line and attempts at connecting all of Craig's previous movies together misfire. review: They legitimately borrowed an Austin Powers Goldmember plot point with their hackneyed attempt at creating emotional resonance between Bond and Christoph Waltz' blofeld. This movie recycled so much from previous films in the Craig era. It tried to give 007 a Bond girl that he truly cared for, but there was none of the chemistry and flair Casino Royale had in the Bond-Vesper relationship. It tried to do the secret organization pulling the strings bit that Quantum of Solace did with Mr. White and the Quantum organization. It tried to do the villain-has-personal-attachment-to-Bond thing that Skyfall did. And on all three fronts, it failed miserably. Worst of all, there were so many dull points in the movie. If you won't have the depth or subversiveness of the better Bond entries, at least have interesting action.

review: This is certainly not the best Bond film to be made, but it's another solid outing for Daniel Craig's 007. I thought the action, as in pretty much all Bond films, was the standout for me. The train sequence was brilliantly choreographed and the climatic scene added some spectacular set piece action that will be etched into the Bond archives. Performance wise all good as expected once more, however Christoph Waltz as the films leading antagonist provided his usual demonic demeanour and his appreance weaves nicely into the narrative that had been building through the films prior to Spectre. This certainly does no harm to a group of films that has built itself up, especially since Craig has been at the helm, as one of the best action franchises of all time.

review: Rating: B "Spectre fails to reach the tremendous potential of its intriguing narrative and fascinating antagonist, but Sam Mendes still pulls off a decent James Bond flick. The screenplay raises significant issues with an incredibly dull subplot that deeply affects the pacing of a bloated runtime. In addition to this, Christoph Waltz's lack of impactful screentime is disappointing, to say the least, despite a brilliant performance from the actor. Fortunately, the jaw-dropping action set pieces elevate the overall film, which also benefits from gorgeous cinematography (Hoyte van Hoytema) and exceptional acting across the board. Daniel Craig and L√©a Seydoux's characters relationship is emotionally compelling, making Bond's mission feel more like an interesting personal journey. One of the best movies of the franchise is buried somewhere under the messy screenplay, but what can be found at the surface has much to appreciate."

review_date: Do I even want to know how Sam Mendes could go from the highs of Skyfall to this? That's rhetorical by the way, don't answer that. The pacing was atrocious, especially because I feel like they could have ended it at the two hour mark, with slight modifications, if any, and called it there. Hey, they brought back other Bond tropes I didn't like, such as storylines just being dropped and never brought back up again. The characters are also a bit flat this time around, the soundtrack's kind of generic, and Daniel Craig is as mumbly as ever, but he does deliver on the actions scenes, so he's done a solid job overall making this his Bond. The visual effects were well done, with neither distracting CGI of most modern blockbusters, nor the awkward mistakes of the 60s/70s/80s. The comic relief is good, and at the end of the day, this is still more interesting than some of the worst ones of the 70s and 80s. I'm really hoping the quality of Skyfall returns, like Bond has 24 times now. I will say, however, the surveillance stuff was timely commentary for 2015 the way Tomorrow Never Dies' was in 1997, and to this day for both, so they were at least trying.

review: Where this film succeeds is in its rich story. Tom Holland does very well in his portrayal of both Spiderman and Peter Parker, and the villain, played by Michael Keaton, is one of the more memorable villains in the MCU. However, the main issue I have with this film is that Spiderman never feels like his own hero, just like Tony Stark's shadow, up until the end of course. Even the villain, however, doesn't even have any conflict with Peter, he just feels like a villain that would fight against the Avengers, or more specifically, Tony Stark. I feel like the film relied too much on Tony Stark and never came out of his shadow. The film in general, however, was still fun to watch and it's one that I've seen several times, it's just that there are a few issues that I have with it.

review: My favourite Spider-Man movie. Tom Holland's version of the hero is the most human between the main trio (him, Tobey Maguire and Andrew Garfield). He's a real teenager: anxious, acts by impulse, he's the Spider-Man who most want to be a hero. Most people complain that Tony Stark replaced Uncle Ben in MCU. I completely disagree. When Peter met Tony he already was Spider-Man by around six months. Uncle Ben has already died and Stark was someone who gave Peter a purpose. His turnaround sentence is the best I saw in a Spider-Man movie. But a Spider-Man movie isn't only made of Spider-Man. We have Peter Parker's arc outside the suit as well. And it's excellent. The high school environment looks like a high school environment (the best friend, the bully, the crush, the cynical, everyone is here and they're great characters) and Tom Holland is the most charismatic and trustworthy Peter Parker (as a teenager, he looks and acts like one) and his chemistry with Laura Harrier (Liz) is undeniably cute. Finally, Vulture is an excellent villain: he's imposing, has a motivation that makes sense, and despite not having Spider-Man as a direct enemy, is a person who is next to Peter and had the superhero interfering in his plans. My only issue with this movie is Aunt May, who is constantly treated like a MILF, and that joke is the only one that is repetitive and never works. It's sad because Marisa Tomei is a good actress and has the perfect age-looking for the role.

review: Spider-Man finally gets a full length MCU treatment in this (sort-of) reboot to the franchise. Tom Holland is probably the most accurate portrayal of our young hero, Peter Parker, as he deals with the after math of working with Iron Man's Avengers (see Civil War). Peter is an easy-going fun loving kid who wants the girl, to impress Tony Stark, and to be popular. The positive in this film is that it is a real coming of age tale with a kid trying to deal with being a kid. Even our villain, The Vulture, is excellently played by (my favourite Batman) Michael Keaton, who has less of a plan and is just plain greedy. This film suffered from a lack of consequences as Peter has nothing really to lose, only his potential position in the Avengers, which isn't that big a deal. The other problem with this film is it can't decide whether it's a teen flick, action movie, coming of age tale or an origin story. Because of this, the plot and pacing can be off at times, but the acting makes up for this as Spidey really shines through.
rt_name: Spider-Man: Homecoming - Movie Reviews

review: My personal/Most rewatchable Spider-Man movie to date. Of course that's not putting down the brilliant Spider-Man 2 from Sam Rami, however this movie is the one I gravitate towards when wanting to put on a Spider-Man film. The Amazing cast really helps push the movie to a higher level with 'Tom Holland' playing Peter Parker/Spider-Man this is the first time I actually believed the actor could actually be in high school whereas former iterations who looked in there mid 20s. Tom Holland to me plays both Spider-Man & Peter brilliantly with Michael Keaton also doing a superb job as the movies villain 'The Vulture' Michael manages to make you feel bad and understand the character one moment then makes you fear him the next, You have to give props to the actor when his powerless character is threatening a superhuman and you are actually worried for the latter. I would 100% recommend this film to any superhero/Spidey fan but I would also recommend this film to casual fans at it is just simply a good & awesome movie.

review: An action-packed coming of age story full of laughs and engaging fight sequences, Spider-Man Homecoming is a cheesy story that doesn't take itself too seriously but still makes time for heartfelt scenes that show who Peter Parker is as a person. The CGI from Marvel is phenomenal, as to be expected. The plot is your average light hearted Marvel plot and it works about as well as you'd expect, the writing isn't some magnum opus but it's decent enough for it to be forgiven. The cast is however a bit hit or miss, Robert Downey Jr is charismatic and a blast as always and Michael Keaton is insidious and one of the better Marvel villains, but we can't speak about the cast without talking about its rendition of Spider-man aka Peter Parker. Tom Holland is truly fantastic, he's cheesy, he's quippy, he's charming, he's everything you could ever want out of a Spider-Man, and most importantly, he's having fun in the role. Unfortunately, outside of these three, the rest of the cast is pretty forgettable. The pacing while at times too fast is never terrible. Overall, Spider-Man Homecoming is a solid first attempt for Marvel at a standalone Spider-Man movie that at times just misses the mark.

review: After what was, honestly, a rather silly and childish first movie, this sequel is far more focused, far stronger in tone, glossier in production, more intricate in its story, and better acted. It's a genuine improvement all around. The way it plays out is almost too dark for some children, but only for the moment itself -- It's dark and scary in the way that children usually love, upon reflection that is. It's scary in the same way as a scary moment in The Neverending Story, or a scary episode of Doctor Who; it's effectively scary but it's not exactly Horror cinema. The fantasy elements are all high-concept and intricate, allowing children to really flex their proverbial thinking muscles, while at the same time they're dazzled by the gorgeous visuals.

review: This accomplishes the main thing that it was supposed to do--build on and expand the world of Harry Potter. It almost does this too much, where the story can sometimes get a bit muddled within all the bright and shiny things to look at. But that is also where much of the charm of the series comes in--where all the tiniest details have been taken into consideration and made to be interesting. Watching this, you WANT to explore Hogwarts with the kids. You WANT to see all the whimsical items in the castle, all the while forgetting there's also a story going on the background. That being said, how much can you truly fault a movie for trying to be interesting?

review: My favorite of the entire Harry Potter franchise, this film has the greatest mysteries, the best build up, an amazing climax and so much amazing character development. It starts off with classic scene after another - Dobby, The Flying Car, The Whomping Willow, The screaming plants - and ends in the dark chamber of secrets in amazing climactic fashion. A cinematic masterpiece, this is maybe the only film that is straight up better than the book. Even just the scenes around Christmas time, the hogwarts scenery alone, the playfulness of the young cast but the very real danger lurking - and who can forget Lockhart, the funniest character in the entire series. This is the Pinnacle of Harry Potter, the grandest of them all. Nearly 3 hours of cinematic masterpiece.

review: After watching Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone I had gotten really high hopes for the Harry Potter franchise. I was expecting all of them to be as simplistic and visually appealing as that movie. With that in mind I watched the second movie today and sadly, it doesn't live up to the mark on almost any of the parameters. That's not to say that it's a bad movie. It's not. But it's not a good Harry Potter movie. To begin with, the movie's CGI hasn't aged pretty well. And that's actually really surprising because the first one was so good so this one should have had a higher budget and thus more advanced VFX. But other than the Basilisk, most of the CGI hasn't aged so well. Especially that of Dobby. When he was banging his head in the drawer in the beginning of the movie, the shelves of the drawer were shaking in the opposite direction of where they should shake. And when Harry puts Dobby in the wardrobe it looked more like the wind is opening the door instead of Dobby. There are plenty of examples of bad CGI in the movie but I don't want to take it too far. Speaking of Dobby, he's had a very bad introduction. The way he is behaving is annoying. If I were to behave like that my mom would have slapped me all across the face. Sure he does get a wholesome ending, but that's yet to see how he turns out. Draco also became more annoying now, with constantly trying to bully Harry even though he can't do a thing. Myrtle spoke like a nerd Harley Quinn. I get this movie is trying to be campy, but that goes way too far. The story is a good part here. Although it's not as easy as Sorcerer's Stone, it is still very nicely detailed. Too many incidents happen in it, but yet it does not feel bloated. It feels absolutely to the point, with none of that "side quest" things movies often use to pad the runtime. Everything happens for a reason and it all pays off in the end. The scenes with Ron, particularly in the beginning, are always funny and memorable. Though Hermione doesn't play as huge part in this movie as Harry and Ron do, she also gets a decent screen time, although without any character arc. I'm still on the second movie of this franchise, so I can't exactly say if this is among the good movies or the bad ones. But I really hope the rest of the movies are more leaning towards the first one in terms of tone. I remember every scene right now, but I can see myself forgetting most of the parts in the next few months.
mojo_name: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets

review: "The Secret Life of Pets 2" was made to teach new parents a lesson Sometimes I feel like Max, the Jack Russell Terrier. As much as I want to be like Rooster, the cool and collective sheepdog, sometimes my nervous and over-protective energy can get the best of me as most new parents have realize in the beginning years. As if Illumination was thinking of me when producing the script, they decided to name the baby Max is zealously protecting over as Liam my own toddler's name. I was only expecting childish fun gags and witty observations about the animals that rule our lives. Never thought the film's moral compass was to make me feel less alone with Max complaining "why is the world so dangerous" as I try to prevent my little ones from hitting themselves into pesky edges in our household. True, this theme is a minor element in this entertaining, energetic, and humorous sequel that should satisfy fans of the original. However, being present in the most important subplot reminded me that the most important lessons can come from unexpected places. As Rooster (perfect voice casting portraying the gruff, aloof, grit, and authenticity of Harrison Ford) said to Max after he reflected paranoia of Liam possibly falling, "so what if he falls? He will just get back up." It's a perfect metaphor that we can't protect our kids at all times forever, to let them go to grow experimenting as Max put it in the end this "complex, scary and beautiful world." Following the model example of Rooster, Max learns to face his own fears giving an example of bravery and courage as a result to Liam. Of course, most people are not going in seeking out these themes in this animated feature rather a visual vibrant, well-pace, and fun time that doesn't outstay its welcome. This film hit that mark overall even feeling more so like an episodic Saturday cartoon. I say that because the structure is unusual considering there is three subplots that feels like three separate episodes that in the end interconnect for a finale. This lack of lasered focus linear structured plot results in a thin story that questions if a sequel only exits simply because its predecessor was a box office success. Nevertheless, at least the themes and lessons learned mentioned earlier intertwines with the three main characters in the final act. At times it seems a bit mature for the younger audience with multiple suspenseful tense scenes however even my toddler son took it well as if he were inspired to become Rooster himself. The voice cast is pitch perfect and strong all around that brings relevance and charm to these characters that will support a healthy fan base looking forward to the next entry. Thank you for the lesson Harrison Ford.

review: I can't help but wonder how many people have died as a result of this movie. It *could* have been a decent movie, but one scene ruined it... when the small dog, suffering anxiety & nervousness issues, had his cone ripped off by the big dog who then threw away the cone away and declared definitively, "You're cured." Anyone who knows psychology or who has suffered recovering from mental illness knows that kind all-to-common action gets people killed. I can't help but remember a friend who introduced me to that movie who during that exact scene and said, "I like that dog." ... as he refused to awknowledge or respect a mental illness his daughter was struggling with; and was just exacerbating her condition. It could have been a decent feel-good movie if it hadn't had that scene. But that scene turned it from a potential tool for healing and recovery to slipping glass shards in the medicine bottle. All in all, for the sake of people's struggling loved ones everywhere, I'm of the opinion that all copies of this movie should be burned.

review: ‚ÄòThe Secret Life of Pets' was a pretty average animated film whose "what do our pets get up to when we're not around" premise made it relatable, funny and charming to pet owners/lovers. The sequel has practically nothing to do with its title anymore (you can only pull that trick once, after all) and loses anything that made it somewhat original. Now we're into very familiar animated-animal territory that we've all seen many times before. Sure, there are some good messages (albeit very standard stuff) and a few things that'll probably make you smile, but for the most part, as with its predecessor, it's not particularly memorable and, in fact, the most stand-out thing is the colourful animation (the backgrounds are lovely) and character design. In short, kids might enjoy it and there are a few moments that might catch your attention, but for most adults, there's not much here.

review: I've watched the movie for a total of 4 times and let me tell you something (two times on HBO and 2 second more on a pirate site): The movie is utterly garbage and unbearable to watch, even with the Utimate Cut. Till now, i still don't know why people are praising a poorly-written movie with extremely low pacing and dogshit performances, maybe because everyone can have diferrent opinions about a subjective subject i guess. Nonetheless, the movie is still something worth to be buried somewhere else outside of this world, far from our reach. There are many problems with the movie, but the biggest problem of all was the plot. It was just unbelievably stupid and corny, left the Martha scene alone. Don't get me wrong, i don't have any personal hate on Snyder but this movie is just something else beyond the conception of intelligence. I refuse to think that this was made by a decent human being. It's like watching a Neil Breen movie for Christ sake, everything is completely a trainwrecking mess. None of the details in it made sense in a way that a nornal mind can conprehend; how can a hateful, violent, gruesome vilgilante somehow found a immigrant alien to be hostile and then spare him the moment he knew that they had the same mother's name? Oh yeah, i know why, because the movie didn't bother to consider the logical thinking of the plot or the self-development of the characters that involved in it so they just did what they thought that be the (least) logical thing to ease the discord between the two. To summarise all of it in one sentence: it's a plain stupid movie.

review: An unbelievably garbled plot leaves me wondering just why so many A listers agreed to take part in it. Paycheque? Surely there has to be more to it than that for such big names as Affleck, Fishburne, Adams. Et Al. The directing is amongst the most hopelessly muddled that I've ever seen in my 65+ years of cinema involvement. (My father was a cinema manager, so that had a bearing on me seeing far, far more movies all through my youth than my contemporaries who had to buy their seats.). But this thing would have had me desirous of a rebate, especially bearing in mind the price of cinema tickets these days, (my days of freebie tickets ended - unfortunately - about thirty years back) The screenplay and dialogue is poor, poor stuff indeed. And - Superman as, effective,y, - a villain? What? I'm reduced to using terms not unrelated to those of abuse in another circumstance. It is crap, it is junk, it is unwatchable dross. Don't buy the DVD, but by all means if you're curious to see how bad a flick Hollywood is capable of turning out despite a vast budget, check it on Amazon Video. Wheee it's a free watch for Prime customers.

review: Wolf Warrior 2 (Rental) is the highest grossing Chinese movie (at this point in time) and is the basis for "wolf warrior" diplomacy. It is in essence a version of Rambo III, set in Africa with a late 1990s direct to video feel and ex-Chinese special forces protagonist. The action scenes sometimes work (the underwater opener and the man v tank showdown) but some are just over the top craziness. It is pro China (in the way most films are pro USA) but it may not be a bad thing, as long as you try to live up to idolized version of your county as opposed to justifying your own actions.

review: Everything about this sequel to Wolf Warrior exceeds the first. The acting, the special effects, the story- all an improvement over the original installment. Wu Jing returns in this sequel. He also wrote, produced, and directed the film. The film surrounds Wu Jing's attempt to live a peaceful life in Africa when he his peace is disrupted by a mercenary army and a deadly disease outbreak. One of my criticisms of the first film was that I did not feel Wu Jing commanded the screen as the lead. Nothing could be further from the truth in this one. Rather than playing a Jackie Chan-esq character, Wu King finds his own as a compelling, interesting, and exciting action star in this one. He is very good. As for the supporting cast- Frank Grillo is always fun to watch. He appears to be the hardest working action star/character in the world. His fight with Jing in the finale of the film is well choreographed. Celina Jade is commanding as the love interest. Nwachukwu Kennedy Chukwuebuka steals every scene he is in as Jing's "Godson". This movie was one of the highest grossing pictures of all time. Sam Hargrave, martial artist, stuntman, and Director of the highly successful "Extraction, stunt choreographed the underwater fight as well as many of the action scenes. This explains a lot about its success. This one is worth watching. The ending foreshadows a "Part 3" and I hope it is at least as good as the sequel.
rt_name: Wolf Warrior II - Movie Reviews

review: In terms of production and narrative machinations, this is a far more complicated movie than its predecessor, so props to Wu Jing on his Directing of this film to have it work; it's not some of the best Directing you'll see by any stretch (the acting is mediocre and some of the cinematography is really rather bland), but it flows and it functions without any actual structural problems, which most certainly isn't nothing. People came to watch Action, and this movie Stars and is Directed by one of the most underappreciated Action stars working today. As such, the action is almost always from Good to Excellent, and the story-beats, while somewhat thread-bare, are enough to keep the momentum up. I was also shocked as to how much had actually happened by the end of the movie, as the amount crammed into the movie feels like it was a full hour longer (not a complaint, just an observation), as it ends with a prolonged fight scene that ends up with him battling a tank. The movie does often times come off as a bit pretentious at times, as it features heroes protecting unarmed citizens from trigger-happy killers, but it really just boils down to being an excuse to have some really cool action sequences; the movie does make you empathize for the refugees, but their part in the movie is really just a trick to generate a sense of empathy from the viewer. There is also a very, very strong Chinese Military Patriotism element in this movie, making it also feel like a Chinese Michael Bay film, but I don't count this against the movie because it makes sense (being a film made in China) and because it's actually purely a positive message - It uses heroism to bestow Patriotic Propaganda but doesn't use it to justify any morally grey misdeeds on the part of the heroes (I mean, it's literally about soldiers protecting unarmed civilians under fire). If you want a fun time you will find it in this movie, which is explosive, full of stunts, and works well on a technical level as well.
