review_date: You can tell they put a good deal of thought into making this one maybe if for no other reason than to give the viewer connections to the original trilogy story. I have to nick the film for a few reasons. It tries so hard in the first half to try and be a drama with Anakin unsure of what he should do. The movie then segways into him completely changing course mentally almost immediately with one scene in particular seeming unbelievable by any stretch - he was conflicted before this scene but he does a complete 180 in seconds and it just seems haphazardly written here. The movie also does a disservice to our prequel heroine, Padme. She is reduced to a stand by your man 'til it kills you 50s style house wife; it's sad because she was a cool woman who could fend for herself in the first two films. She's turned into a prop here and it's only her acting that saves it from being a wash. Last ding is that it's hard to believe the Jedi didn't know the Sith Lord was right in front of them the whole time; they're supposed to be wise and have prophetic abilities. All that to say this: there are some great battle sequences including the best lightsaber battle in the series. The back and forth storytelling works well here to keep the viewer engaged. I can't say the film is easy to watch in the middle - Anakin's transition into Vader is not only convoluted but disturbing. It's especially hard to watch in juxtaposition to the rest of the series' tone. We can assume things about good and evil but to see Vader's fall from grace is very depressing. It is easily the least enjoyable 40ish minutes to watch in the whole saga. The first 40 and last 40 minutes however are enough to make it not only good but the best in the prequels. As a standalone story it is well done but not a movie you'll want to rewatch for fun - it's essential to the overarching story and that's it.

review: Though the film can get a bit uneven at parts, the conclusion is ultimately satisfying and heartbreaking to watch as it wraps up this mediocre trilogy with spectacular fashion. "Revenge of the Sith" has the best story, CGI, and action of any of the prequel films made, and the film perfectly sets the stage for "A New Hope." I think that George Lucas had a perfect plan with this trilogy, though ended up failing in the process to get to this film. This third installment in the prequel trilogy is absolutely gorgeous to watch, and due to its very memorable and emotional moments throughout, "Revenge of the Sith" remains as one of the best "Star Wars" movie to date, despite its several flaws.

review: It's was very refreshing to watch such a great movie after Star Wars Episode 1 and 2, which both were very disappointing. One problem was the writing, it's poorely written and could have been better. The fight choreography was amazing and the end fight got me emotional. It explains Anakin's tragedy very well and the morality of the Jedi Order too. Great movie, i would suggest to Star Wars The Clone Wars Season 7 after the movie. There you have a bigger explanation of events and it goes much deeper into the tragedy of the fall of the Jedi Order. 8.5/10

review: This move is 10/10 and I'm willing to die on that hill. The sound score, the fight choreo, Ewan McGregor's performance, and the way it tied the prequels to the originals were amazing. I see a lot of people complain that Anakin is "too whiny" when that's literally how he's supposed to be. He's an emotionally stunted man with childhood trauma who was drafted into a cult of religious soldiers at the age of 10. Also, no hate to Luke but I distinctly remember him being very whiny in A New Hope. This movie embodies what Star Wars is and is a thrilling yet heartbreaking conclusion to the prequels that shaped so many of our childhoods.
mojo_name: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith

review: Star Wars Revenge of the Sith is my personal favorite Star Wars Movie. It brings the Prequel Trilogy to an exciting, dramatic, and emotional end helping shape timeline wise the next movies to come (the Original Trilogy) The story is an exciting one and contains some of the best duels in all of Star Wars which is strengthen by John Williams incredible soundtrack. The emotion and chemistry showcased between Anakin (Hayden Christensen) and Obi-Wan (Ewan McGreggor) is what makes the film hit even harder. Years later this movies popularity and view in the fanbase continues to grow as more and more people see the film for what it is, an incredible Star Wars movie.

review: Revenge of the Sith is my second favorite Star Wars films and deserves much more recognition and respect than it receives. This film encapsulates the Star Wars cannon by showing the transition of Anakin into one of the most feared foes in film history, Darth Vader. The film reveals the corruption and evil veiled by politics and society that ruptures the galactic republic and tilts the tides of good vs. evil. Definitely a must watch film! Fun fact: this film has the longest "sword-fight" in film history.

review: A very underrated movie. This film accomplished what the prequel trilogy was aiming to do, which was to elaborate on the backstory of Darth Vader and Palpatine's rise to power through the corruption of the republic. We are shown how Palpatine's manipulation of Anakin comes to fruition after years of careful planning. We see the failure of the Anakin Obi Wan relationship and the establishment of Luke and Leia's upbringings. This film also has an amazing score, including some of John William's finest works such as Battle of the Heros and Duel of the Fates. This film also makes excellent parallels with the rise of Hitler and the fall of democracy in post WW1 Germany. I do have some issues with this film, namely some of the acting is a little over the top. I also think the handling of Padme's death was rather cheesy. I think it would have been more fitting if it was eluded that Palpatine killed her instead of heartbreak. Overall a great film that deserves less hate that it gets.
mojo_name: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith

review: Star Wars Episode 3 The Revenge of the Sith (A) Might get some flack for this opinion but I don't care. This was my favorite movie growing up and I still have so much nostalgia for it. Anyone born in the 90s that is a star wars fan probably agrees that this was such a fun time to watch as a child. I remember my first time watching it and how amazing it was to see obiwan become ben and Anakin become Darth Vader. This inspired me to love movies the way I do today. Looking back at the movie now I definitely will note the cheesy dialogue here and there but it is still such a solid movie. I LOVE the lightsaber battles in this movie. I thought Ewan McGregor as obiwan was a perfect cast and Ian McDermott as Darth sidious is terrifying. Everyone should agree that this is by far the best of the prequel trilogy. George Lucas finally nailed one of the movies after his amazing original trilogy. Nothing but love from me here...

And it's amazing.

review_date: Catching Fire, the second (and best) film in The Hunger Games series is an absolutely phenomenal film. While I enjoyed the first film a lot and I thought it was a great adaptation of the novel, this film is 10x better. The stakes are higher, the acting is better, the cinematography is nauseating. It is everything a sequel should be. This film has such an incredible fast pace and energy to it that makes it so enjoyable to watch. We also meet new characters in this film like Finnick and Johanna, who are also my two favorite characters in the series. My only main complaint is that I do think it feels a little bit too similar to the first film since we do have to go through all the training and interviews and prepping all over again since Katniss has to go back into the games. But it‚Äôs still great to watch none the less, also Stanley Tucci as Ceaser Flickerman is amazing. Overall, Catching Fire is a phenomenal sequel and a phenomenal film in general.

review: Now this is how you do a sequel and adaptation! Francis Lawrence translated the book into film so incredibly well it makes me so happy. Once again, every actor and casting is amazing especially Jennifer Lawrence. Each gives a passionnate, exciting and emotional performance. The riots and all the political stuff is so intriguing and handled really well and gives the first half clear stakes and makes it really intense. The movie is also paced much better. Deapite a few rushed scenes, every scene is as long as it needs to be and makes the experience very smmoth. Now, about the Hunger Games aspect. Seeing old winners and other districts was one of my favorite parts of the book so I was happy that Lawrence nailed that aspect, especially with Finnick and Johanna, whose characters are captured perfectly. Hell, every character is handled really well. The design for the arena is inspired and incredible and the action is creative, intense and filmed much better. It's clear Lawrence really wanted to please fans of the book and he did. Wish they added the scenes of the previous Hunger Games and some scenes like Katniss's judging were longer but overall, a great adaptation.

review: Guardians 2 is a strong follow up to the original film, somehow creating more depth and humour with each character. The only weakness lies in an over-saturation of what made the first film so special, which was the subtle humour mixed with classic music. These wonderful elements now are more blatant and over the top. Saying this though, this is the Marvel sequel we were all waiting for, incorporating unknown characters without brow-beating us about upcoming films in the MCU, potential spin-offs and sequels and just creating more depth in the Guardians universe. I am looking forward to Adam Warlock being featured in the sequel.

review: This film is definitely a step-up from the first installment as the story is just so much better. James Gunn really poured a lot into this movie which led to such an amazing film. The overall message of the movie is so beautiful and offers so many iconic moments. The film always has something going on and a lot of the story details never get lost in other plots. Some aspects of the film are a tiny bit complicated, but it doesn't hurt the movie all that much. A large reason why this movie feels a lot more whole is that the characters are way better developed here. Peter's story excels greatly into something really beautiful. I would even say the same about Yondu as in the first film, Yondu didn't feel all that important. This film, however, made me greatly appreciate Yondu and his actions in the first film. Rocket, Gamora, and Nebula also get some more character development that I think benefited them greatly. Even new characters like Ego and Mantis were very easy to attach some type of connection to as they are both very well developed. The only character I would say is poorly written is Drax, which sucks because I really liked Drax in the first film. Drax came off as rude and annoying for a large part of the film and his jokes weren't all that funny this time around. As much as I loved the characters in this film from a story standpoint, the actors weren't all that great. Both Chris Pratt and Zoe Saldana do a poor job in their roles. Their line delivery is off some of the time and I never felt the energy their performances had in the first film. Plus, both actors never convinced me that they had a love connection forming. Another actor that struggled was Dave Bautista. He was sometimes trying too hard to sell his joke or line that it came off in a cringeworthy way. However, the rest of the cast was pretty solid. Bradley Cooper did a fantastic job just like in the first film and new additions to the franchise Kurt Rusell and Pom Klementieff do an awesome job with both really nailing down the personalities of their characters. Michael Rooker is the stand-out to me in this film. Rooker had some great line delivery and really made the message of the film feel powerful and impactful. The production design of this film was flawless. Everything looked so stunning and the design of Ego's planet was just so well done. The color choices were great and how the technology on the planet moved was just so cool to watch. However, the cinematography felt a little weaker in this film. It was still very good, but I don't think cinematographer Henry Braham really made any shots look visually breathtaking like Ben Davis did in the first film. Something that did improve was the score. It was better than in the first one with Tyler Bates creating some memorable tracks and more of a balance between songs and the score. Overall, Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 was definitely a step-up storywise, but somewhat of a step-down when looking at some of the cast. Even though I do like this film better than the first one, I do think the cast was a lot better in the first installment rather than the second. However, the strong, heartfelt story really hides all the casts' flaws and really sets this film over the top. Read more reviews like this at postcreditreviews.com
rt_name: Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 - Movie Reviews

review: The first Guardians of the Galaxy was a lot of insanity and a fair amount of heart -- this Sequel has a fair amount of insanity and a lot of heart. And I really mean it - much of the movie does ask that you feel "this is funny" or "this is cool", but there are numerous parts where the movie make you feel Mortified, Triumphant or even legitimately Sad. The final few minutes of the movie before the credits roll are absolutely spellbinding, and I literally tear-up every time I watch the final act of this movie. The final act is both Inspiring and then Heartbreaking shortly afterwards, and the fact that a Marvel movie has, upon multiple viewings, brought me to tears really shows how outstanding this film is. Like many, I would've liked a bit more insanity, but this is EASILY the Second Most Insane movie of the MCU (part 1 being the #1 spot), and since the trade-off was genuine emotional impact, I am more than happy with the exchange we got. If you love movies that cover a wide spectrum of emotions and does so effectively, then Guardians of the Galaxy 2 might be the best movie to do so in a very long time. You will laugh, you will cheer, your heartrate will occasionally rise and you will end it having had your soul crushed. In terms of pure entertainment and emotional impact and satisfaction, I'd argue this might be the best Space Opera since The Empire Strikes Back - yes, I really mean that.

review: GotG Vol. 2 isn't quite as good as its predecessor, but even though it does fall into the "sequel is worse" category, it still remains a solid and entertaining MCU blockbuster and comes close enough to the original to be enjoyable. The script doesn't have the finesse of the first movie causing the humor to drag and be a little over the top at points, but the actors do a fine job of getting around this causing a few of these moments to be genuinely funny. It's nice that this movie takes us deeper into the character of Peter Quill by exploring his family, a route that was set up well at the end of Guardians 1. What's even better about this is watching how Peter learning about and discovering his true family impacts his relationship with his "new" family: his fellow Guardians. This impact adds some emotional depth to the film, and makes Peter Quill a surprisingly complex character and takes him through a really nice arc that forces him to truly consider his relationships with those he cares about the most. Pratt supplements this with another great performance as the character, and his fellow Guardians castmates hit the spot as well. The movie makes sure to make good use of Kurt Russell as Ego by giving him plenty of screen time, a backstory, and a few emotional moments of his own. It also kicked ass to see the true power and capabilities of Yondu's flying arrow, something we got a taste of in the first movie but was amplified substantially in this movie. It's also still a relief and breath of fresh air that this film has no connection to the Avengers and the rest of the cinematic universe other than us knowing that it's a part of it. As mentioned before, what really prevents this movie from reaching the heights of GotG 1 for me is the humor, since even with the acting the script hampers this movie's ability to be as funny as GotG 1. GotG 2 is nonetheless still a fun and entertaining movie and is sure to leave viewers satisfied as the credits roll.

review: The emotions of an eleven year-old girl named Riley are brought to life inside her head as they move from Minnesota to San Francisco. The voice casting in this film is amazing! Amy Poehler, Phyllis Smith, Lewis Black, Bill Hader and Mindy Kaling are terrific as Joy, Sadness, Anger, Fear and Disgust respectively. Them and Richard Kind as Bing Bong drive this film. This film has so much thought put into it (pun intended)! The way they portray things like memory, abstract thought, dreams, depression, etc., is so creative and somewhat educational. The finale also brings a great emotional lesson for anyone. Not only is the story and backgrounds creative, but the animation and attention to detail is simply astounding and makes this film worth watching repeatedly. This movie is a must watch!

review: Pixar has made movies of all kinds - What if toys had feelings, what if insects had feelings, what if monsters had feelings, what if cars had feelings, what if fishes had feelings, what if rats had feelings. And now they have made Inside Out - what if feelings had feelings? Inside Out is probably one of the most underrated movies that Pixar has made. It was the first original Pixar movie which I didn't get to know about when it released (the first such one was a sequel, Monsters University), and I'm really surprised how this movie gets overlooked so easily. The way I see it, this movie is a social commentary about how we perceive life with our emotions. Riley here is a metaphor of us, how we feel when we move to a new place and are unable to handle the new life. In such situations we either feel scared, angry or depressed. When Riley starts crying in class, Joy tries to stop Sadness from ruining her memory with a vacuum but ends up destroying all her other memories. This is another metaphor from our lives, where we end up forgetting all our happy memories in times of desperation. Later on Joy and Sadness are in her memories, where they see Riley's childhood drawing of Bing Bong whom she considered her friend. The plot has been made with a complete sense of nostalgia. When we feel nostalgic, we feel both happiness and sadness at the same time. We are happy because we got to live those times, the time which was better than what we are living at the moment. We are sad because we know that time never stops, and so everyday we are straying further away from when it happened. We will never be able to live the day again, and it shall only stay in our memory. While Joy and Sadness are not present Fear, Anger and Disgust control her. I don't think I need to explain this. Riley has lost all her happiness and does not feel any sadness. Keep in mind she had previously cried in class, which is something very embarrassing for a ten year old child. As a result she does not want to show her sorrow in front of everyone since she fears people will laugh at her, so instead she tries to cover it with anger and disgust. This is just like how we behave when we are depressed but are also too afraid of what others might think if they learn about it. And then there is the memory dump, the place where the old memories are forgotten. This is one of the deepest messages that the movie gave us. To save Joy and Sadness and allow them to get out of the pit, Bing Bong readily sacrifices himself. This is because he had always considered himself and Riley friends, and he was ready to sacrifice his own life for this. It also shows how Riley has now lost the memory of Bing Bong due to her depression and frustration, and it is something she will never remember again. This is a metaphor of how we forget the small details from our childhood which gave us joy once we grow out of the phase. It also symbolises that although Bing Bong has been lost forever, Riley's joy and sadness will always remember him. This is similar to how we get nostalgic whenever we see our childhood writings and drawings. And finally when Joy and Sadness do make it back, then Joy chooses to let Sadness guide Riley. If she wanted she could have guided Riley and make her feel happy about reuniting with her parents. But in that case the moment would have completely lost the impact. So instead Sadness did it, which is why Riley started crying, something she had not done for a long time. This is yet another metaphor of when we are unable to hold our sorrow for too long and burst out crying. As a result her parents are finally able to understand the situation she is in and give her more love. In the end Riley starts feeling happy, since everyone has understood the value of Joy. She was the first emotion that Riley felt, and the one who guided them all in the time of desperation. All the other emotions came to her afterwards, which is why they are not as emotionally attached to Riley as Joy does. Joy knows what is the best for her, just like how we feel the best thing for our life is what makes us happy.

review: Just‚Ä¶.how? How did Pixar make another flawless film after three films that I would either consider meh or bad? I just don't get it! Let's just make sure Pete Doctor directs every Pixar movie ever and we will be a-ok. I don't want to talk about all the good things with this movie, because let's face it: everyone has done that. Instead, I want to talk about all the things that this Pixar movie does better than all the others. First, I think this is the best voice cast for any Pixar movies prior or after this. The only one that kind of comes close for me is Toy Story 4, but that's for a different review. Biggest highlight is of course the great work of Amy Phoeler as Joy, it was just spot on. Next, comedy. Seeing how the main character is literally the concept of Joy, I would like to think that this movie was going to be funny. And I was right with this being, in my personal opinion, the funniest Pixar movie. Lewis Black as Anger is just a laughing riot to me. He was hilarious! Finally, how can you not talk about this movie without mentioning the ending, with two big emotional parts that really leave a huge impact. The first being the death of Bing Bong, which feels a little like it comes out of nowhere, but you're going to remember it. And, of course, when Riley comes home from running away and the parents also say that they miss the old home‚Ä¶.OMG it's so good! The only kind of problem is that Anger is mainly the reason all the islands get destroyed, and no one addresses it at any moment. But that's minor, and no one is going to be thinking that in their first viewing, I only noticed it in my most previous viewing of the movie anyway. I really think someone should do a deeper dive into this movie, cause it really deserves it. However, I can only praise it for so long. Go to Disney+ and watch this flawless film and to see the best Pixar has to offer!

review: Inside Out review A heartfelt animated movie, "Inside Out", takes you on a rollercoaster of emotions with creative imagination and a look back at some nostalgic moments we might have had in our childhood. Unlike any other, Pixar studios created an original movie of the emotions that go behind a person's mind and made them into having their own personalities. Focused on the mind of a little girl ,Riley her life is shown as typically any perfect childhood. With the presence of the emotion joy it shows her story of her two loving parents raising her and living the life with many moments that one child creates. Including the building of humor, friendship and playing your favorite sport. But as all children go through the other emotions such as sadness, fear ,disgust and anger it will include her experiences. However, her life takes a sudden turn when she has to move with her parents from their hometown Minnesota to San Francisco. Her emotions will be put to the test in adapting to a new lifestyle they're typically unused to. To start off , it shows the beginning of the first years in Riley's life. Transitioning from stages to the preteens years of her life. This is where she experiences many emotions and personal likeness and dislikeness. Riley is seen on her journey as she experiences all typical childhood memories. From learning how to walk to talking your first new words. Discovering your least favorite meal to favorite toy to take with you everywhere. The laughter you create and the sad moments you experience. The rewarding moments of receiving a good grade to being upset for losing an important game. As Riley is growing she has experienced majority exciting emotions until a certain news comes to her attention. She will be moving from her childhood home Minnesota, where she was born, raised, and grew up to miles away into the city of San Francisco. Despite the change , her emotion Joy makes Riley see all this in a positive way. Meeting new friends, decorating a new room and many more ideas. Arriving at the new location, Riley is quick to notice the drastic change in seeing her new home. Adapting to the city and less outdoor activity is one of the unfortunate changes making her find new adventures. On her first day of school, she is introduced to her classmates and told to talk a bit more from her time back home. As she recalls some of her favorite memories, the emotion sadness touches her favorite memory, changing Riley's memory to a sad moment and turning it into a sorrowful memory. Joy continues to try and make Riley enjoy the new memories. After they had another similar disagreement Joy and Sadness cause the core memories to be knocked from their containers and accidentally vacuumed along with them into Riley's emotional interior. With this problem, it leaves the other emotions Fear, Disgust and Anger to run the emotions until the others return changing RIleys behavior. Throughout the film it shows the many obstacles and challenges Joy and Sadness must go through to reach the headquarters. Following with revisiting old memories and lifelong imaginary friends. It will take a spin through some future glimpse some being Riley's future boyfriend and many more. Overall this unfortunate event turned out to be a better lesson. The emotions appreciating each other's teamwork to help Riley have the best life she could as she grows up. Enjoying the moments one creates as living life with a positive attitude.

review: Normally, Almost every animation which are made by Disney and Pixar are interesting to most people because they mostly fun, happy to watch, beautiful graphic, etc. , but I think 'Inside out' is more than that. I have remembered that in the time this movie has been released, it was very famous. But I have not seen it yet until two months ago that I watched it. The first time I have seen this movie to the end. I understood to many media why they rated this animated movie very high. First It is about the graphic of the animation. As we have known. Disney and Pixar are one of the best animation studios about graphic, and they have done to this movie very well, such as an appearance of a character. There are lots of details about graphic, sharpness of the video, etc. Second, sound effect. In my opinion. Sound effect are very important to every movie in the scenes that want to show, or express more the feeling to the audiences than only the movie scene. And this movie expresses the feeling to the audiences very well such as happy, sad, scared. The last thing and it is the most interesting point is about feeling. It is what this movie expresses to us. For me, this part is the point that makes this movie different to other animation movies that Disney and Pixar have made. It is more than a movie for entertaining. It teaches us how we can control our feeling , however I will not tell you what feeling that I mean. I want you find it by yourself in the movie. Then after you watch it, you will understand what I have told to you. But there is one inferior point in this movie. It is distribution of the character. Some characters are very notable, but there are few characters have a few of air time, scenes that they act. In my opinion, 'Inside out' is still one of my best animation movie. For me, I give it 1/3 of the best Disney and Pixar movie of all time. If anyone is looking for some full of quality movie. 'Inside out' is the great choice. concluding, very well work for Disney and Pixar making this movie. I give 9 out of 10. I hope you enjoy my review more or less. Thank you so much!

review: A significant improvement to the original "Thor" movies, "Thor: Ragnarok" is a hilarious film that provides plenty of action and humor to go with its plot, which was pretty good as well. The film takes the MCU to many new places, and perfectly sets the stage for Infinity War. The direction that this film goes in is steady, and the story never strays from its goal. The comedy is another thing that is done very well, although I feel like it is overdone at some parts where it probably should've been more serious. Still, I really enjoyed this movie and it was definitely better than the other "Thor" movies.

review: I hated this movie because I didn't like the "heroes" or agree with their Machiavellian quest to mind f@#k someone in the name of antitrust. It is wrong to drug people and them mind r@pe them as they lay unconscious and helpless. It is better to institute and enforce anti-trust laws that would break up large giants like Google and Amazon. We can't have economic freedom without bodily autonomy and basic civil liberties as well as a government that enforces those liberties. Kidnapping Fischer was a vicious, cowardly and morally bankrupt and not the work of a hero. I disliked the character so much I didn't care what happened to them so the movie was boring as well. The fact this ham fisted, pedantic and desultory film is supposed to be "intelligent" is particularly disturbing. Imagine a future where computer nerds rule the world by forcibly kidnapping us and then implanting "good" ideas into our brains and those of our children to make sure we do the "right" thing. Would you care if one of those nerds got killed going too "deep" into your brain while you lay unconscious and helpless? That is the way I felt watching Fischer's kidnapping.

review: This one takes multiple viewings to truly enjoy. I really wanted to like this movie like everyone else and wasn't fully satisfied or thrilled the first time I watched it. Then I watched it again and appreciated the extremely impressive elements of it much more. The directing talent from Christopher Nolan is truly remarkable and the special effects/CGI is great. The action scenes especially in the middle of the film were my favorite parts, plus the ending scene. Not to mention the cast of actors that they were able to have participate in the production, very noteworthy. The film does have some issues though that may alienate some viewers. Much of the phenomenon in the movie is left up to a lot of interpretation and can make your mind too blown while you're still trying to keep up with the plot. It can be a lot to take in all at once and confuse people who aren't used to a movie like this. Plus I think that the romance between Cobb and Mal bogged down the main mission of the team a little too much, but I still see why something like that was included. Overall a pretty good movie! There is a lot to say about this movie and many ways to analyze it and that's why it was popular I guess!

review: A perfectly paced, written and directed story that will send your mind to an endless pondering and mesmerising journey. Nolan really knows what he's doing when it comes fiction. He knows how to deliberately lose the audience's comprehension to then retrieve it with magnificence. What truly makes Nolan's famous fiction movie Inception a masterpiece of time and reality mayhem, is the way the story is written and developed. It starts with a pretty strenuous concept: the inception of dreams. But then, as the story unwraps, with well-pace actions, embracing dialogues and great characters dissections, we begin to fathom what this concept of infiltrating dreams can serve for, alongside how it actually works ‚Äì using great insight of true physics and thorough studies upon the very subject of dreams and time. All leading to an ending that wraps into this "open ways" notion. The casting is straight up perfect. Leonardo DiCaprio embraced the role of Dom Cobb as a professional, really diving into the trauma of the protagonist and exploiting the pain and adventurous errands that this character went through in his past. Tom Hardy nailed the role of the Eames, a character capable of impersonating others within one's dream, using his seriousness and his passionate sheer acting. Cillian Murphy, managed to play the role of a broken son left with the legacy of his dead father like a boss, using his prowess acting and his bewitching voice. And last, but not least, Eliott Page, who really knows how to do her job and create an emotional and interesting character, Ariadne, ready to help her team as the ingenious architect of dreams. I could spend a day writing about the story and how the cast, the full cast, is perfectly chosen, but I think the points I've given are enough to catch your attention ‚Äì without spoiling the whole narrative ‚Äì if you haven't seen the movie yet.
rt_name: Inception - Movie Reviews

review: Compelling if not a bit convoluted. review: There are few objectively bad cinematic experiences that I like as much as the Michael Bay Transformers movies, but Part 2: Revenge of the Fallen, is the one I will never rush to defend. It's aggressive, it's loud, it's obnoxious, it's WAY too long, and I never thought I'd say this about a Michael Bay movie, but: It feels Lazy. This last one is the biggest oddity in regards to this movie, as Michael Bay's biggest problem has always been that it feels like he Directs and Edits after drinking a double-dosage of RedBalls Energy Drink (for those that watched Chapelle Show), but half of this movie looks like Bay just Directed it after taking Melatonin, as the cinematography is surprisingly plain, the stunts less intense than his usual work, the action blocking is a lot less intricate than with any other movie of his, and there's so much in this movie that simply did not need to exist that it felt like Bay was shooting most of this out of obligation. Let's throw in the fact that this movie is simultaneously the Most Comedic yet Least Funny entry of his Transformers movies, and you also have a movie that suffers greatly from inconsistent tone (a problem the others suffered from as well but not nearly to the degree here). The one distinctly good moment in this movie is a desperate fight in the forest between Optimus Prime and several Decipticons, as it's one that plays out with genuine stakes, has weighty consequences, ends on a powerful note and feature's excellent cinematography, choreography and sound design. It's a shame as this bit is genuinely great, the sole legitimately shining moment in a movie that balances between low-tier mediocrity and the outright awful.

review: When I had heard everyone say that Transformers movies keep getting worse as time moves on I was actually very hesitant to watch this. I really liked the first movie so there was no way I could believe that THIS franchise could possibly be bad (although I did see that later on, I didn't see it here). In my review of the first movie I said how I got interested in the Transformers franchise after watching it, since I didn't know this was actually a toys company and not an anime series. If that movie was just the introduction, this was where the real action takes place. I saw Revenge of the Fallen on Amazon Prime soon after the first one. I only had one week left before my Prime subscription would expire, so I had only decided to dedicate this time to watching all the Transformers movies so that I could understand what this franchise is all about. Unlike the future movie this one actually expanded on what was established at the first movie. Although the human characters were not as interesting as the previous movie and the story was also pretty much empty, the action scenes completely made up for it. As usual the CGI and action was very good. The new characters introduced were fun to watch. I really like to see it when new characters are brought in and given their own character development as they transform into cool cars. However not everything about this movie was good. Like I said above the human characters were not as interesting. The entire blood about Sam going to college and his parents continuously pestering him was very annoying. This was the last time we got to see Mikaela, which is also something very sad IYKWIM. This movie was able to explain very well the entire concept of Transformers, something that the prequel fail to do so. Before I used to think that Autobots and Decepticons are supposed to be cars, but now I know that they are actually robots which can turn themselves into whatever they see in front of them. I would definitely give a rewatch afterwards sometime in the future whenever I have to show this franchise to a new generation.
rt_name: Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen - Movie Reviews

review: This may be controversial, but I believe Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen is one of the best films in the franchise. This film is slightly messy, but only if you don't pay attention. The movie isn't finished yet, and you can tell; there are some funny awkward jokes strewn around, and there are a few minor narrative holes here and there, but I can see where they're heading, and I LOVE it. The plot is very interesting to explore, including the history of Transformers and the lasting effects of that legacy that transcends time. Also you will not find better action in any other film than in this one; the action is nonstop and visually appealing and it will keep you at the edge of your seat. All in all, my childhood favorite and an actually enjoyable watch.
rt_name: Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen - Movie Reviews

review: The best of the five Twilight Saga films, "Breaking Dawn: Part 2" - because it is the end! Yes, but it also rises above the other four because it is NOT a sappy film wallowing in the morose, moonstruck moodiness of the eternal love between Bella (Stewart) and Edward (Pattinson). Rather it is mash-up, and just an ok mash-up, of the "Underworld" and the "X-Men" series of films with some decent, and distracting, vampire characters with special skill (who knew this about vampires?!) and an above average climatic fight scene that turns out rather unexpectedly. Was it worth sitting through over 10 hours of these five films? That will remain highly unlikely other than for the most diehard fans.

Bella developing her vampire gift as well as meeting other vampires who are seasoned in their gifts and fighting to protect her vampire family from the Voulturi brings this final chapter to it's ultimate end. I'm so glad that happily ever after comes around for Bella and Edward and they get to enjoy it with their daughter.

review: I liked the first part of "Breaking Dawn" enough to make me curious about this movie. While I do think the opening and closing moments of the movie are solid, I think this movie seriously drags in the middle. For a movie that is supposed to be the big finally, this movie is super underwhelming. As usual, the acting and dialogue aren't great, but this movie mercifully doesn't focus much on the unconvincing romance in this series. I just feel the way it ends is kind of a cop-out, happily ever after type of ending, and it makes the whole series feel a bit pointless. I can't speak on behalf of the book but I think this franchise saw an opportunity to make some money and dragged this story into two full-length movies when in reality just one big two and a half hour movie might have been handled more neatly and effectively. As it stands, this isn't the worst "Twilight" movie but I can't say it is one of the better ones either.

review: To tell a tale out of school, out of all the horrible Worst Picture Razzie winners, Twilight: Breaking Dawn Part 2 was the main reason I retained from doing this marathon in the first place. On top of not getting into the teenage vampire and werewolf trend in early 2010's, I didn't want to expose myself to the cinematic bubonic plague known as the Twilight franchise. Unfortunately, the 8-year record is broken as I have now seen one of their movies, the final one. Previously, Bella Swan-Cullen (Kristen Stewart) gave birth to Edward Cullen's (Robert Pattinson) half-vampire baby Renesmee (Mackenzie Foy). In Part 2, Bella and Edward's love-child brings a conflict between the Cullen family, the pack of werewolves lead by Jacob Black (Taylor Lautner) and the Volturi cult led by Aro (Michael Sheen). Having not seen the other films or read the Stephanie Meyer books, I could never follow why being immortal would be a threat to the Volturi vampires or how the vampires inexplicably gain powers like chopping logs like a cheese cracker, superspeed, or super-jump. It also didn't help that the visual effects are far below the standards of a Sci-Fi channel movie, demonstrated by the werewolves, motion blurs, the backdrops, and the baby. Another list of stupidity: Bella learning to act human, the elemental powers that contribute nothing to vampirism, the ethnic stereotypes, and the climactic battle near the end which was all a vision. The only redeeming and entertaining value in the whole series so far is Michael Sheen, who bites the scenery gloriously and even has that silly hammy laugh as an act of threat. While nicely shot and not with some crazy and funny moments, Breaking Dawn Part 2 is still a poorly written, poorly acted and poorly directed mess. (1 ¬Ω Ugly CGI Renesmee Cullens out of 5)

review: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn - Part 2 is seriously boring. Nothing happens for the entire movie, but, don't worry, it's all building up for the much anticipated finale when. . .nothing happens. For most of the movie, characters stand around, stare at each other and occasionally recite lines. The only eventful part of the story is nothing but a cheap fake-out. Without Rifftrax, I wouldn't have made it through this terrible film. Good riddance, Twilight.

review: The best Twilight film...mostly owing to the fact that it's the last one of these suckers (no pun intended). There's a final battle that's actually quite badass, despite being remarkably gore-free for an all-out massacre...which then leads to probably the cheapest movie cop-out I've ever seen in a movie, though I won't spoil it for you. Michael Sheen has more screen time after being limited to just two scenes in the terrible New Moon movie and only allowed to have a Marvel-style mid-credits scene cameo in the last movie. And, the movie for once isn't boring with some nice cinematography and a decent opening credits sequence. It's still not good despite being the best film but I'd rather take an average fantasy action film than a dull romance anytime. Kristen Stewart and Robert Pattinson's performances aren't any different from what we're used to seeing from them at this point, the ending is probably not as happy as Stephenie Meyer and Bill Condon seem to think it is and it's clear the special effects budget was dedicated to just the final battle because Bella and Edward running looks abysmally fake and the CGI baby is much more creepy here than in Part 1. Did I mention the cheap cop-out? I think I did. Glad to get this franchise over with though I might see the adaptation of The Host, seeing how the book is written by the same author. It is fascinating to see how a series that was always generally considered to be not good still managed to have movies that were all hugely successful at the box office. While there have been good first films followed by a series of crappy sequels such as Transformers and the Resident Evil movie series, Twilight was considered to be a bad film franchise from many detractors since day one yet the sequels still managed to show up amongst the 10 highest-grossing films of the year from 2009 to 2012. We might never get a definitive answer as to just how popular this series ended up being but for the time being, let's all take a moment and feel either relieved or sad that this series has come to an end.
